{{Infobox musical artist | name = 1788-L | background = temporary | image = | birth_name = | birth_date = | genre = {{hlist|[[Electronic music|Electronic]]|[[new beat]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|[[Record producer]]|[[Disc jockey|DJ]]|[[musician]]}} | instrument = [[Digital audio workstation]] | origin = | years_active = 2018–present | label = Deadbeats | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Illenium]]|[[Said The Sky]]|[[Rezz]]|4AM|Blanke}} | website = {{URL|1788-L.com}} }} '''1788-L''' is an [[electronic music]] producer.{{cite web|author=Meadow, Matthew|title=1788-L Is Already Getting Lots Of Hype After Only Three Tracks|work=YourEDM|url=http://www.youredm.com/2018/02/23/1788-l-already-getting-lots-hype-three-tracks/|accessdate=26 March 2018}}{{cite web|title=1788-L Drops One Of The Most Insane Daft Punk Remixes We Have Ever Heard|work=EDMSauce|url=https://www.edmsauce.com/2018/03/02/1788-l-drops-one-insane-daft-punk-remixes-ever-heard/|accessdate=27 March 2018}}{{cite web|title=Dexter's Beat Laboratory Vol. 32|work=Dancing Astronaut|url=http://www.dancingastronaut.com/2018/03/dexters-beat-laboratory-vol-32/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} They rose to fame in 2018 with a remix of [[Porter Robinson|Virtual Self]]'s "Particle Arts" uploaded onto their [[SoundCloud]] account.{{cite web|title=Virtual Self- Particle Arts ( 1 7 8 8 – L / F L I P )|work=EDMSauce|url=https://www.edmsauce.com/2018/02/13/virtual-self-particle-arts-1788-l/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} Other releases following this include "Multiverse" (with 4AM) and a remix of [[Daft Punk]]'s "Rinzler".{{cite web|author=Evanson, Austin|title=Premiere: Daft Punk – Rinzler (1788-L Remix)|work=[[Dancing Astronaut]]|url=http://www.dancingastronaut.com/2018/03/premiere-daft-punk-rinzler-1788-l-remix/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} ==Career== On 26 January 2018, 1788-L uploaded their debut release, "Replica", on [[SoundCloud]].{{cite web|title=R E P L I C A by 1788-L|work=[[SoundCloud]]|url=https://soundcloud.com/1788-l/replica-22|accessdate=27 March 2018}} A [[music download|digital download]] release of they song was issued on 2 February 2018.{{cite web|author=1788-L|title=Replica - Single|work=[[iTunes Store]]|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/replica-single/1342467838|accessdate=27 March 2018}} On 9 February 2018 they released a remix of "Particle Arts" by [[Porter Robinson|Virtual Self]]. On 2 March 2018, a remix of [[Daft Punk]]'s "Rinzler" (from ''[[Tron: Legacy (soundtrack)|Tron: Legacy]]'') was released, and premiered on [[Dancing Astronaut]].{{cite web|title=Premiere: Daft Punk – Rinzler (1788-L Remix)|work=Dancing Astronaut|url=https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/03/premiere-daft-punk-rinzler-1788-l-remix/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} On 30 March 2018, a remix of "[[Radioactivity (song)|Radioactivity]]" by [[Kraftwerk]] was released.{{cite web|title=1788-L Drops Newest Track, A Remix Of Kraftwerk’s “Radioactivity”|work=YourEDM|url=https://www.youredm.com/2018/03/30/1788-l-drops-newest-track-a-remix-of-kraftwerks-radioactivity/|accessdate=3 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=1788-L Drops A Fire Remix of a Kraftwerk Classic|work=EDMSauce|url=https://www.edmsauce.com/2018/03/30/1788-l-drops-a-fire-remix-of-a-kraftwerk-classic/|accessdate=3 April 2018}} His debut extended play, ''[[Sentience (EP)|Sentience]]'', which comprises four tracks was released on August 24, 2018 through [[Zeds Dead]]' label, Deadbeats. 1788-L performed their first live show on July 7, 2018 in [[Los Angeles, California]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.youredm.com/2018/07/08/half-of-soundcloud-showed-up-to-1788-ls-crazy-debut-in-la-last-night/ |title=Half of Soundcloud Showed Up to 1788-L's Crazy Debut in LA Last Night |last=Meadow |first=Matthew |date=July 8, 2018 |website=Your EDM |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180708222226/https://www.youredm.com/2018/07/08/half-of-soundcloud-showed-up-to-1788-ls-crazy-debut-in-la-last-night/ |archive-date=July 8, 2018 |accessdate=August 25, 2018}} ==Discography== ===Extended plays=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:7em;"| Title ! style="width:15em;"| Details |- ! scope="row"| ''[[Sentience (EP)|Sentience]]''{{Cite web |url=https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/08/1788-ls-destructive-debut-ep-s-e-n-t-e-n-c-e-finally-arrived/ |title=1788-L’s destructive debut EP, ‘S E N T I E N C E,’ has finally arrived |last=Norris |first=Asher |date=24 August 2018 |website=[[Dancing Astronaut]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180825021038/https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/08/1788-ls-destructive-debut-ep-s-e-n-t-e-n-c-e-finally-arrived/ |archive-date=25 August 2018 |accessdate=25 August 2018}} | * Released: 24 August 2018 * Label: Deadbeats * Format: [[Music download|Digital download]] |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" ! {{Infobox professional wrestler |name = A-1 |image = A-1withJadeChung20041212.jpg |alt = |caption = A-1 (right) with [[manager (professional wrestling)|valet]] [[Jade Chung]] after capturing the [[BCW Can-Am Heavyweight Championship]] on December 12, 2004. |birthname = Alastair Charles Ralphs |names = '''A-1'''
'''A1'''
'''A-One'''
Alastair Ralphs
Alistair Ralphs
Allistar Ralphs
Buddy Austin |height = {{height|ft=6|in=0}}{{cite news|title=Statistics for Professional wrestlers|work=PWI Presents: 2007 Wrestling Almanak and book of facts|publisher=Kappa Publications|id=2007 Edition|page=38}} |weight = {{convert|256|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1977|5|22|mf=y}} |death_date = |alma_mater = [[University of Windsor]] |birth_place = [[Placentia, Newfoundland and Labrador|Placentia]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]]. [[Canada]] |resides = [[Dunnville, Ontario]], Canada |billed = [[Niagara Falls, Ontario]] |trainer = [[Scott D'Amore]] |debut = 2001 |retired = }} '''Alastair Charles Ralphs''' (born May 22, 1977) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[professional wrestling|professional wrestler]] and former [[Bodybuilding|bodybuilder]], better known by his [[ring name]], '''A-1''' (alternatively spelled '''A1''' or '''A-One'''). He is best known for his appearances with [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]] (TNA) from 2004 to 2007 as part of [[Team Canada (TNA)|Team Canada]]. ==Early life== Ralphs was born in [[Placentia Bay]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]], and relocated to [[Dunnville, Ontario|Dunnville]], [[Ontario]] at the age of five. He later moved to [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]], [[Ontario]] to attend the [[University of Windsor]]. ==Professional wrestling career== ===Border City Wrestling (2001–2005)=== Alastair Ralphs was trained by [[Scott D'Amore]] in the Can-Am Wrestling School, and debuted in D'Amore's [[Border City Wrestling]] promotion in 2001. After spending three years as an [[job (professional wrestling)|undercard talent]], Ralphs became A-1, a cocky, arrogant [[heel (professional wrestling)|heel]], forming an alliance with [[Joseph Dorgan|Johnny Swinger]]. He defeated [[D'Lo Brown]] for the BCW Heavyweight Championship on December 12, 2004, in [[Belleville, Michigan]] at "[[A Night of Appreciation for Sabu]]". On January 23, 2005, at New Year's Revolution, Ralphs interrupted the Hall of Fame induction ceremony, complaining that he was being overshadowed by older wrestlers. Scott D'Amore responded with a jibe aimed at Ralph's previous career as a [[Bodybuilding|bodybuilder]], leading to a brawl between Ralphs and D'Amore. Following a distraction from Jade, A-1 was able to powerbomb D'Amore through a table. Ralphs went on to retain the heavyweight title in a match with [[Abyss (wrestler)|Abyss]], using Abyss's own chain to knock him unconscious. Ralphs lost the BCW Heavyweight Championship to [[Bobby Roode]] on July 22, 2005. In the course of his reign as champion he faced well-known veterans such as [[Jim Neidhart]] and [[King Kong Bundy]]. ===Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (2004–2007)=== On July 16, 2004, Ralphs appeared in [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]], losing to [[Sabu (wrestler)|Sabu]]. He reappeared on March 13, 2005 as a member of [[Team Canada (TNA)|Team Canada]], replacing the injured [[Johnny Devine]] at [[Destination X (2005)|Destination X 2005]] and teaming with Bobby Roode, [[Eric Young (wrestler)|Eric Young]] and [[Petey Williams]] to face [[Chris Harris (wrestler)|Chris Harris]], [[James Storm]], [[Brian Gerard James|B.G. James]] and [[Konnan]]. He wrestled on [[TNA Impact!]] throughout April and May 2005, [[tag team|teaming]] with other members of Team Canada or accompanying them to the ring. At [[TNA Hard Justice|Hard Justice]] on May 15, Ralphs took part in the [[Gauntlet for the Gold]]. He entered at number six and was eliminated by [[Monty Sopp|The Outlaw]] and B.G. James. On the May 11, 2006, episode of ''[[TNA Impact!]]'', [[Larry Zbyszko]] asked Team Canada coach [[Scott D'Amore]] for assistance in his feud with [[Raven (wrestler)|Raven]]. D'Amore eventually agreed to help Zbyszko rid TNA of Raven, and nominated A-1 to face Raven in a match at [[TNA Sacrifice#2006|TNA Sacrifice 2006]] in May 2006, a match that A-1 lost. On the June 29, 2006, episode of ''Impact!'', TNA Management Director [[Jim Cornette]] disbanded Team Canada. A-1 soon began wrestling sporadically, facing Ron Killings in the pre-show of the Hard Justice pay-per-view and against Eric Young at the No Surrender pay-per-view, losing both times. He also took part in the Kevin Nash Open Invitational X-Division Gauntlet Battle Royal at Bound For Glory, despite not being a part of the X-Division. He was eliminated by both [[Matt Bentley|Maverick Matt]] and [[Frankie Kazarian|Kazarian]]. A-1 was released by TNA in February 2007. ===Independent circuit (2007–present)=== Since leaving TNA, A-1 has wrestled on the independent circuit in Canada and the United States. At [[Impact One Night Only]]: Canadian Clash in February 2018, A-1 returned to [[Impact Wrestling]] for the first time in over 11 years, unsuccessfully challenging [[Eli Drake]] for the [[Impact Global Championship]]. He returned to Impact Wrestling once again at the following month's One Night Only: March Breakdown PPV, where he teamed with [[Allie (wrestler)|Allie]] in a victory over [[Braxton Sutter]] and KC Spinelli. He is also currently a member of the [[Border City Wrestling]] roster. ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[Border City Wrestling]]''' **[[BCW Can-Am Heavyweight Championship]] ([[BCW Can-Am Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/other/2004-12.html | title=Independent Wrestling Results – December 2004 | accessdate=2008-07-05|publisher=onlineworldofwrestling.com}} *'''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''' **PWI ranked him #'''253''' of the top 500 singles wrestlers in the [[Pro Wrestling Illustrated#PWI 500|PWI 500]] in 2007http://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=1841&page=12 ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|2693399|A-1}} *[http://www.accelerator3359.com/Wrestling/bios/a1.html A-1 at Accelerator3359.com] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070318074502/http://www.tnawrestling.com/fullnews.php?home=255 Interview conducted by Bill Banks] {{BCW Can-Am Heavyweight Championship}} {{DEFAULTSORT:A-1}} [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Canadian bodybuilders]] [[Category:Canadian male professional wrestlers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Placentia, Newfoundland and Labrador]] [[Category:Professional wrestlers from Newfoundland and Labrador]]

revision.text:
[[File:Report dog bites LCCN93511152.tif|right|thumb|1941 poster for the Cleveland Division of Health encouraging dog bite victims to report dog bites to the proper authorities]] {{Dynamic list}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}}
'''Animal attacks''' are a cause of human injuries and [[Death|fatalities]] worldwide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs373/en/|title=Animal bites|website=World Health Organization|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref> Up to five million people in the U.S. are attacked by cats and dogs each year.<ref name="yep">{{cite web|url=http://www.uptodate.com/contents/animal-bites-beyond-the-basics|title=Patient education: Animal bites (Beyond the Basics)|publisher=UpToDate|accessdate=2017-02-27}}</ref> The frequency of animal attacks varies with [[geographical]] location. In the United States, a person is more likely to be killed by a domesticated dog than they are to die from being [[lightning strike|hit by lightning]] according to the [[National Safety Council]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Injury Facts Chart | publisher=National Safety Council| url = http://www.nsc.org/learn/safety-knowledge/Pages/injury-facts-chart.aspx | accessdate = 2015-04-09 }}</ref>
Animal attacks have been identified as a major [[public health]] problem. "Unprovoked attacks occur when the animal approaches and attacks a person(s) who is the principle attractant, for example, predation on humans..."<ref>{{cite book | last = Angelici | first = Francesco | title = Problematic wildlife : a cross-disciplinary approach | publisher = Springer | location = Cham | year = 2016 | isbn = 978-3-319-22246-2 }}</ref><ref name= WHObites>{{cite web | publisher = World Health Organization | title = Animal bites |date = February 2013 | url = http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs373/en/| accessdate = 2017-02-27 }}</ref> In 1997, it was estimated that up to 2 million [[animal bites]] occur each year in the United States.{{Citation needed|date=October 2016}} Injuries caused by animal attacks result in thousands of [[death|fatalities]] worldwide every year.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Warrell|first1=D.A.|title= Venomous bites and stings in the tropical world|journal=Med J Aust|date=1993|volume=159|issue=11–12|pages=773–779|pmid=8264466}}</ref> All causes of death are reported to the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] each year. Medical injury codes are used to identify specific cases.<ref name=Langley>{{cite journal|last1=Langley|first1=Ricky L.|last2=Morrow|first2=William E.|title=Deaths resulting from animal attacks in the United States|journal=Wilderness and Environmental Medicine|date=1997|volume=8|issue=1|pages=8–16|pmid=11990139|doi=10.1580/1080-6032(1997)008[0008:drfaai]2.3.co;2}}</ref> The [[World Health Organization]] uses identical coding, though it is unclear whether all countries keep track of fatalities caused by animals.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} Though animals, excluding some tigers, do not regularly hunt humans, there is concern that these incidents are " ...bad for many species 'public image'.”<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.quora.com/What-animals-like-to-eat-humans |title=What animals like to eat humans? |publisher=Quora |date= |accessdate=2017-04-10}}</ref> Though some pets will feed on people if they die, are sick or unconscious, this is not characterized as an attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/natashaumer/cats-eat-your-face-after-you-die |title=Horrifying Stories Of Animals Eating Their Owners |publisher=Buzzfeed.com |date=2015-01-08 |accessdate=2017-04-10}}</ref>
== Injuries and infections == Bite injuries are often the consequences of an animal attack, including those instances when a human attacks another human. Human bites are the third most frequent type of bite after dog and cat bites.<ref name=Cherry2014>{{cite book | last = Cherry | first = James | title = Feigin and Cherry's textbook of pediatric infectious diseases – Animal and Human Bites, Morven S. Edwards | publisher = Elsevier/Saunders | location = Philadelphia, PA | year = 2014 | isbn = 978-1-4557-1177-2|postscript=; Access provided by the [[University of Pittsburgh]] }}</ref> [[Dog bites]] are commonplace, with children the most commonly bitten and the face the most common target.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.dogbitelaw.com/PAGES/statistics.html |title= Dog Bite Statistics |author= Kenneth M. Phillips |date= 2009-12-27 |accessdate= 2010-08-06 }}</ref> In 1936, amputation was required in one third of cases in which treatment was delayed for 24 hours or longer.<ref name=Cherry2014 />
== Epidemiology and treatment == Animal bites are the most common form of injury from animal attacks. The US estimated annual count of animal bites is 250,000 human bites, 1 to 2 million dog bites, 400,000 cat bites, and 45,000 bites from snakes. Bites from skunks, horses, squirrels, rats, rabbits, pigs, and monkeys may be up to 1 percent of bite injuries. Pet ferrets attacks that were unprovoked have caused serious facial injuries. Non-domesticated animals, though assumed to be more common especially as a cause of rabies infection, make up less than one percent of reported bite wounds. When a person is bitten, it is more likely to occur on the right arm, most likely due to defensive reactions when the victims uses her or his dominant arm. Estimates are that three quarters of bites are located on the arms or legs of humans. Bites to the face of humans constitutes only 10 percent of the total. Two thirds of bite injuries in humans are suffered by children aged ten and younger. The subsequent treatment for those who have been attacked (if they survive) depends on the injuries. Though trauma may be addressed first, subsequent infections are also treated with appropriate antibiotics.<ref name=Cherry2014 />
Up to three fourths of dog bites happen to those younger than 20 years-old. In the United States, the costs associated with dog bites are estimated to be more than $1 billion annually. The age groups that suffer most from dog bites are children 5 to 9 years-old. Often, bites go unreported and no medical treatment given. As many as one percent of pediatric emergency room visits are for treatment for animal bites. This is more frequent during the summer months. Up to five percent of children receiving emergency care for dog bites are then admitted to the hospital. Bites typically occur in the late afternoon and early evening. Girls are bitten more frequently by cats than they are by dogs. Boys are bitten by dogs two times more often than girls.<ref name=Cherry2014 />
== Medical codes for animal attacks == Injuries resulting from encounters with animals occur with sufficient frequency to require the use of [[medical codes]] by clinicians and [[insurance company|insurance companies]] to document such encounters. The [[ICD-10-CM]] Diagnosis Codes are used for the purpose of clearly identifying [[disease]]s, their causes, [[injury|injuries]] in the United States. [[Clinician]]s use these codes to quantify the medical condition and its causes and to bill insurance companies for the treatment required as a result of encounters with animals. * [[dog bite]]s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/V00-Y99/W50-W64/W54-|title=2017 ICD-10-CM Diagnosis Codes W54.* : Contact with dog|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = 2015/16 ICD-10-CM Diagnosis Codes W55.* : Contact with other mammals | url = http://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/V00-Y99/W50-W64/W55- | accessdate = 2015-10-16 }}</ref> * [[dolphin]]<ref>{{cite web | title = 2015/16 ICD-10-CM Diagnosis Code W56.0 : Contact with dolphin | url = http://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/V00-Y99/W50-W64/W56-/W56.0 | accessdate = 2015-10-16 }}</ref> * [[sea lion]]<ref>{{cite web | title = 2015/16 ICD-10-CM Diagnosis Code W56.1 : Contact with sea lion | url = http://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/V00-Y99/W50-W64/W56-/W56.1 | accessdate = 2015-10-16 }}</ref> * [[orca]]<ref>{{cite web | title = 2015/16 ICD-10-CM Diagnosis Code W56.2 : Contact with orca | url = http://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/V00-Y99/W50-W64/W56-/W56.2 | accessdate = 2015-10-16 }}</ref> * fish<ref>{{cite web | title = 2015/16 ICD-10-CM Diagnosis Code W56.5 : Contact with other fish | url = http://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/V00-Y99/W50-W64/W56-/W56.5 | accessdate = 2015-10-16 }}</ref> * [[mouse|mice]]<ref>{{cite web | title = 2015/16 ICD-10-CM Diagnosis Code W53.0 : Contact with mouse | url = http://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/V00-Y99/W50-W64/W53-/W53.0 | accessdate = 2015-10-16 }}</ref> * [[rat]]<ref>{{cite web | title = 2015/16 ICD-10-CM Diagnosis Code W53.11 : Bitten by rat | url = http://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/V00-Y99/W50-W64/W53-/W53.11 | accessdate = 2015-10-16 }}</ref> * [[squirrel]]<ref>{{cite web | title = 2015/16 ICD-10-CM Diagnosis Code W53.29 : Other contact with squirrel | url = http://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/V00-Y99/W50-W64/W53-/W53.29 | accessdate = 2015-10-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2014/02/14/when-squirrels-attack-theres-a-medical-code-for-that/|title=When squirrels attack! There’s a medical code for that.|publisher=}}</ref>
== African buffalo == In the early 1990s one African village suffered at least one human death and more than one attack from buffalo in the area of their village. The attacks stopped after a fence was built around the village to protect it.<ref>"Outcomes of a Community Controlled Wildlife Utilization Program in a Zambezi Valley Community", Gordon Edwin Matzke and Nontokozo Nabane; Human Ecology, Vol. 24, No. 1 (Mar., 1996), pp. 65-85</ref>
== Arthropods ==
[[Bee]]s, [[wasp]]s, [[scorpion]]s and other stinging or biting [[arthropod]]s cause human fatalities but these are not as often characterized as 'attacks'. It may be difficult to characterize some of these encounters as offensive or defensive. An arthropod 'attack' instead of causing tissue [[trauma (medicine)|trauma]] such as cutting, lacerating, crushing or the severing of body parts may instead cause a [[physiological]] reaction that results in human death. These effects are [[toxic]] effects and [[allergic]] effects.
Listing deaths due stings and allergic reactions from arthropods is not practical but some of the more unusual cases include:
=== Ants === In 2006 a 68-year-old [[South Carolina]] woman died after being attacked by [[fire ants]] while gardening.<ref>{{cite web|title=Beware of the Bugs: Fire Ants Can Kill Americans|publisher=ABC News|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Health/story?id=2143091|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref> Residents in nursing homes have been attacked.<ref>deShazo RD, Kemp SF, deShazo MD, Goddard J. (2004) Fire ant attacks on patients in nursing homes: an increasing problem. Am J Med. 116(12):843-6. {{PMID|15178500}}</ref>
[[Jack jumper ant]]s have caused numerous fatalities. In 1931 two adults and an infant were killed in [[New South Wales]] allegedly from jack jumper ants or ''[[Myrmecia pyriformis]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cleland|first1=J.B.|title=Insects in Their Relationship to Injury and Disease in Man in Australia. Series III|journal=The Medical Journal of Australia|date=1931|volume=2|page=711}}</ref> In 1963 another caused by an ant attack documented in [[Tasmania]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Trica|first1=J.C.|title=Insect Allergy in Australia: Results of a Five-Year Survey|journal=The Medical Journal of Australia|date=24 October 1964|volume=2|pages=659–63|pmid=14213613}}</ref><ref name=1986clark>{{cite journal|last1=Clarke|first1=PS|title=The natural history of sensitivity to jack jumper ants (Hymenoptera formicidae ''Myrmecia pilosula'') in Tasmania.|journal=The Medical Journal of Australia|date=December 1986|volume=145|issue=11–12|pages=564–6|pmid=3796365|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/19366302_The_natural_history_of_sensitivity_to_jack_jumper_ants_%28Hymenoptera_formicidae_Myrmecia_pilosula%29_in_Tasmania|accessdate=29 November 2014}}</ref> Identification of venom allergens began in the early 1990s.<ref name=FordSA>{{cite journal|last1=Ford|first1=SA|last2=Baldo|first2=BA|last3=Weiner|first3=J|last4=Sutherland|first4=S|title=Identification of jack-jumper ant (''Myrmecia pilosula') venom allergens|journal=Clinical and Experimental Allergy|date=March 1991|volume=21|issue=2|pages=167–71|pmid=2043985|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2222.1991.tb00826.x}}</ref> all in Tasmania and all due to [[anaphylactic shock]].<ref name=brown2001st>{{cite journal|last1=Brown|first1=SG|last2=Franks|first2=RW|last3=Baldo|first3=BA|last4=Heddle|first4=RJ|title=Prevalence, severity, and natural history of jack jumper ant venom allergy in Tasmania|journal=The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|date=January 2003|volume=111|issue=1|pages=187–92|pmid=12532117|doi=10.1067/mai.2003.48}}</ref><ref name="AVRU">{{cite web|url=http://www.avru.org/?q=general/general_jumper.html|title=Jumper Ants (''Myrmecia pilosula'' species group)|last=|first=|date=|work=Australian Venom Research Unit|publisher=University of Melbourne|accessdate=24 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=qldbull>{{cite web|title=Bull and Jumper Ants|url=http://www.qm.qld.gov.au/Find+out+about/Animals+of+Queensland/Insects/Ants/Common+species/Bull+and+Jumper+Ants#.U_nwefmSxvo|publisher=Queensland Museum|accessdate=24 August 2014}}</ref>{{efn|The total number of deaths from this 20 year period due to the ant could be higher. One account reports of another fatality in Tasmania and one in New South Wales.<ref name=Kenneth2002>{{cite journal|last1=McGain|first1=Forbes|last2=Winkel|first2=Kenneth D.|title=Ant sting mortality in Australia|journal=Toxicon|date=August 2002|volume=40|issue=8|pages=1095–1100|doi=10.1016/S0041-0101(02)00097-1|pmid=12165310}}</ref>}} The fatality rate was one person every four years from the sting.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Guest|first1=Annie|title=Vaccine underway in Tas' for 'Jack jumper' ant bite|url=http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2005/s1305089.htm|accessdate=5 December 2014|work=The World Today|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=17 February 2005}}</ref>
=== Bees === [[Africanized honey bee]]s are known to attack people unprovoked.<ref>{{cite news | title = Neighbors react to killer bee swarm in Desert Hot Springs |work= KESQ — News Channel 3 |location=Palm Springs, CA | url = http://www.kesq.com/news/person-rushed-to-hospital-after-being-attacked-by-bees-in-dhs/31758410 | accessdate = 2015-04-06 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Killer Bee Attack Leaves 1 Dead, 4 Injured In Arizona |publisher=Huffington Post | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/10/09/killer-bee-attack-arizona_n_5956544.html | accessdate = 2015-04-06 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Killer Bees Kill Texas Couple |date= 21 April 2011|publisher=Huffington Post | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/04/21/killer-bees-kill-couple-texas_n_852287.html | accessdate = 2015-04-06 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Killer Bees Attack Florida Man And Firefighters; Kill Dog | publisher = Huffington Post | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/19/killer-bees-florida_n_3113991.html | accessdate = 2015-04-14 }}</ref>
=== Hornets === [[Asian giant hornet]]s in China have killed at least 42 people and injured 1,675 more.<ref>{{cite web | title = Giant Asian Hornets Are Killing People In China, Breeding In Larger Numbers|publisher=Huffington Post| url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/01/giant-asian-hornets-killing-people-china_n_4023249.html | accessdate = 2015-04-14 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Deadly giant hornets kill 42 people in China|first= Madison |last=Park |first2=Dayu |last2=Zhang |first3=Elizabeth |last3=Landau|date=2013-10-04| url = http://edition.cnn.com/2013/10/03/world/asia/hornet-attack-china/index.html?hpt=hp_c3 |work=[[CNN]]| accessdate = 2015-04-14 }}</ref>
=== Scorpions === {{Main|Scorpion sting}} Although about 2000 species exist, only about 25-40 species can deliver enough venom to cause serious or lethal damage to humans. One of the more venomous or potentially dangerous species, especially for infants, young children, and the elderly in the United States is Centruroides exilicauda or bark scorpion. Most scorpion stings vary from small swelling to medically significant lesions in severity, with only a few able to cause severe allergic, neurotic or necrotic reactions. Only two species of scorpions can inflict stings which result in death of normal healthy humans: the Israeli deathstalker (Leiurus quinquestriatus) and the Brazilian yellow scorpion (Tityus serrulatus).
=== [[Yellow jackets]] === *1998 – A two-year-old boy died in Tampa, Florida when yellow jackets stung him.<ref>{{cite web | title = Yellow jackets kill toddler|publisher= Tulsa World: News | url = http://www.tulsaworld.com/news/yellow-jackets-kill-toddler/article_23bd2208-1224-522d-8609-1e3b6df98c37.html | accessdate = 2015-04-20 }}</ref> *2002 – An 83-year-old man died when yellow jackets stung him while doing yardwork in Hillsborough County, Florida.<ref>{{cite web | title = Yellow jackets swarm, kill man |publisher=St. Petersburg Times | url = http://www.sptimes.com/2002/04/16/TampaBay/Yellow_jackets_swarm_.shtml | accessdate = 2015-04-20 }}</ref> *2013 – A family in Atlanta, Georgia, were attacked and hospitalized.<ref>{{cite web | title = Hundreds of yellow jackets attack mother, young kids |publisher= WSB TV-2 | url = http://www.wsbtv.com/news/news/local/hundreds-yellow-jackets-attack-mother-young-kids/nbP84/ | accessdate = 2015-04-20 }}</ref>
== Bears == {{Main|Bear attack}} 162 bear attacks were reported in the United States between 1900 and 1985. This is about two reported bear attacks per year.<ref name=Cardall331>Cardall, Taylor Y. and Peter Rosen. "Grizzly Bear Attack" ''[[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]]'' p. 331.</ref> During the 1990s bears killed around three people a year in the U.S. and Canada.<ref name=Cardall331 /><ref name=Fergus97>Fergus, Charles. ''Wild Guide: Bears'', p. 97</ref> A [[American black bear|black bear]] killed three teenagers in [[Algonquin Park]] in Canada.<ref name="kruuk" /> The majority of attacks happened in national parks.<ref name="attacks">''A Book of Man Eaters'' by Brigadier General R. G. Burton, Mittal Publications</ref> 1028 incidences of black bears acting aggressively toward people, 107 of which resulted in injury, were recorded from 1964 to 1976 in the [[Great Smoky Mountains National Park]].<ref name="kruuk">''Hunter and hunted: relationships between carnivores and people'' by Hans Kruuk, published by Cambridge University Press, 2002, {{ISBN|0-521-89109-4}}</ref> After a 20-year ban, Florida is considering legislation that may permit bear hunting to stop the expanding population of black bears that are a menace in suburban neighborhoods.<ref>{{cite web | title = Florida Mulls Return Of Bear Hunts After Increase In Urban Attacks|publisher=Huffington Post | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/02/04/florida-bear-hunt_n_6611036.html | accessdate = 2015-04-14 }}</ref>
=== Asian black bears === [[Asian black bear]]s are comparatively more aggressive toward humans than those of Europe.<ref name="brown">''Bear Anatomy and Physiology'' from Gary Brown's ''The Great Bear Almanac'', Lyons & Burford, Publishers, 1993</ref> In India, attacks have increased. These occur near the Himalayan region. Here, attacks increased from 10 in 1988–89 to 21 in 1991–92.<ref>"Human-bear interactions" from ''Status and management of the Asiatic black bear in India'' by S. Sathyakumar in ''Asiatic Black Bear Conservation Action Plan'', chapter 10 of ''Bears: Status Survey and Conservation Action Plan'' compiled by Christopher Servheen, Stephen Herrero and Bernard Peyton, published by IUCN/SSC Bear Specialist Group</ref> Recent bear attacks on humans have been reported from [[Junbesi National Park]] and [[Langtang National Park]] in Nepal, and occurred in villages as well as in the surrounding forest.<ref name="nepal">{{cite web|url=http://www.bearbiology.com/fileadmin/tpl/Downloads/URSUS/Vol_18/U18_1_Stubblefield_and_Shrestha.pdf|title=Status of Asiatic black bears in protected areas of Nepal and the effects of political turmoil|publisher=}}</ref> [[Li Guoxing]], the second person in history to have received a [[facial transplant]], was a victim of a black bear attack.<ref name="titleXinhua — English">{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2006-04/15/content_4426709.htm|title=Xinhua – English|accessdate=25 November 2007|work=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014015822/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2006-04/15/content_4426709.htm|archivedate=14 October 2007|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="titleBBC NEWS|Asia-Pacific|'First face transplant' for China">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4910372.stm|title='First face transplant' for China|accessdate=25 November 2007|work=BBC News|date=14 April 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014125952/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4910372.stm|archivedate=14 October 2007|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Between 1979–1989 nine people were killed in Japan .<ref name="NE">{{cite book|author=Knight, John|title=Natural Enemies: People-Wildlife conflicts in Anthropological Perspective|year=2000|page=254|isbn=0-415-22441-1}}</ref> In 2009 one bear attacked a group of tourists in central Japan.<ref name="japan">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8265084.stm|title=BBC NEWS – Asia-Pacific – Bear attacks tourists in Japan|publisher=|accessdate=20 December 2014}}</ref>
=== European brown bears === {{Main|Eurasian brown bear}} Brown bears are considered unpredictable.<ref name="attack">''Bear Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance'' by Stephen Herrero, Hurtig Publishers Ltd./ Edmonton 1985</ref> In 2007, a fatality occurred in [[Finland]] from an attack by a European brown bear.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=De Giorgio|first1=Fabio|last2=Rainio|first2=Juha|last3=Lalu|first3=Kaisa|title=There attack-A unique fatality in Finland|journal=Forensic Science International|date=15 November 2007|volume=173|issue=1|pages=64–67|pmid=18401885|doi=10.1016/j.forsciint.2006.08.026}}</ref> Typically one or two people are attacked rather than groups, with no attacks being recorded against groups of more than seven.<ref>{{cite web|title=Alaska Bear Incident Update: NOLS Students Injured in Bear Attack in Alaska|publisher=National Outdoor Leadership School|url=http://nols.blogs.com/nols_news/2011/07/press-release-nols-students-injured-in-bear-attack-in-alaska.html|accessdate=30 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202115246/http://nols.blogs.com/nols_news/2011/07/press-release-nols-students-injured-in-bear-attack-in-alaska.html#|archive-date=2 February 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== [[Grizzly bear]]s and [[American black bear]]s === {{Main|List of fatal bear attacks in North America}}
=== Polar bears === Polar bear attacks on humans are extremely rare, as humans generally do not live near their habitats. Polar bear attacks can happen in captivity like [[Binky (polar bear)|Binky]] at the [[Alaska Zoo]] when he mauled an Australian tourist Kathryn Warburton when she jumped over two safety rails to get a close-up photograph of Binky in his enclosure but stuck his head through the bars and grabbed her and she suffered a broken leg and bite wounds. Six weeks later, Binky was involved in another mauling. Drunken local teenagers approached the bear's enclosure, apparently hoping to swim in its pool, and one 19-year-old was hospitalized with leg lacerations after he was mauled.
== Birds ==
=== Cassowaries === When a cassowary attacks, it will charge and kick and even jump on top of the person. Cassowaries are described as being able to use their legs to kick in a forward and downward motion. They are also able to head-butt and charge. The most common injuries that are sustained by those who are attacked consist of puncture wounds, lacerations and bone fractures. The severity of the injuries are increased if someone is crouching or lying flat. The large birds will attack dogs and cats. Dogs attack cassowaries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/tetrapod-zoology/how-dangerous-are-cassowaries-really/ |title=How Dangerous Are Cassowaries, Really? - Scientific American Blog Network |publisher=Blogs.scientificamerican.com |date=2016-06-08 |accessdate=2017-04-10}}</ref><ref name="Kofron1999">{{cite journal|last1=Kofron|first1=Christopher P.|title=Attacks to humans and domestic animals by the southern cassowary (Casuarius casuarius johnsonii) in Queensland, Australia|journal=Journal of Zoology|volume=249|issue=4|year=1999|pages=375–381|issn=0952-8369|doi=10.1111/j.1469-7998.1999.tb01206.x | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jzo.1999.249.issue-4/issuetoc}}</ref> * 1926 – a 16-year-old [[Queensland]] boy<ref>{{cite book|last=Christensen|first=Liana|title=Deadly Beautiful: Vanishing Killers of the Animal Kingdom|year=2011|publisher=Exisle Publishing|location=Wollombi, NSW|isbn=978-1-921497-22-3|page=272}}</ref><ref>Kofron, Christopher P., Chapman, Angela. (2006) "Causes of mortality to the endangered Southern Cassowary Casuarius casuariusjohnsonii in Queensland, Australia." ''Pacific Conservation Biology'' vol. 12: 175–179</ref>
=== Ostriches === In 1997, a woman in [[South Africa]] was killed while walking through a field on an [[ostrich farm]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Ostrich Kicks A Woman To Death In South Africa |publisher=Chicago Tribune | url = http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1997-12-29/news/9712300244_1_ostrich-cape-town-death-in-south-africa# | accessdate = 2015-04-08 }}</ref>
=== Swans === Anthony Hensley, 37, was kayaking in Illinois when two swans managed to flip his boat, drowning him in April 2012.<ref name="oddee.com" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/16/kayaker-drowns-swan-attack-anthony-hensley-illinois_n_1428331.html|title=Swan Attack Causes Anthony Hensley's Death; Kayaker Drowns In Illinois|first=Andy|last=Campbell|date=16 April 2012|publisher=|via=Huff Post}}</ref>
===Birds of Prey=== Some evidence supports the contention that the [[African crowned eagle]] occasionally views human children as prey, with a witness account of one attack (in which the victim, a seven-year-old boy, survived and the eagle was killed),<ref>Steyn, P. 1982. Birds of prey of southern Africa: their identification and life histories. David Phillip, Cape Town, South Africa.</ref> and the discovery of part of a human child skull in a nest.
== Bulls ==
[[Bull]]s attack and kill people on farms.<ref>{{cite web|title=Union County man killed by bull|publisher=The Columbus Dispatch|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2012/09/07/bull-kills-man.html|accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bull kills man in Paducah|publisher=The Southern News|url=http://thesouthern.com/news/local/bull-kills-man-in-paducah/article_9e3ff26e-81ee-5286-b747-5680f4e325e2.html|accessdate=21 March 2015|first=Dustin|last=Duncan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bull kills man in Iowa County|publisher=WXOW News 19 La Crosse, WI|url=http://www.wxow.com/story/17307640/bull-kills-man-in-iowa-county|accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref>
During 2010, a man and woman were walking through a field where a bull was pastured. The man was killed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Man charged after bull kills rambler|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/aug/06/man-charged-bull-kills-rambler|date=19 September 2013|accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref>
== Canids ==
=== African painted dogs === On November 4, 2012, a two-year-old boy lost his life when [[African wild dog|African painted dogs]] mauled him after he fell into their exhibit at the [[Pittsburgh Zoo & PPG Aquarium|Pittsburgh Zoo]]. Zookeepers immediately rushed to that area, trying to fire darts in order to frighten the dogs away, and police shot one particularly aggressive dog, which had refused to retreat from the exhibit when called. The other dogs were quarantined for thirty days but there were not plans to put them down.<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-update-pittsburgh-zoo-dogs-20121105,0,45834.story Pittsburgh Zoo says 2-year-old was killed by [[dog]]s, not fall], LA Times, Matt Pearce, November 5, 2012. “ . . The zoo passed recent inspections and "discouraged" visitors from putting children on such railings, Baker [zoo chief executive] said, although she did not elaborate on whether there were specific policies or regulations in place. . ”</ref><ref name=WildDogsEatBaby>{{cite web|url=http://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2012/11/04/child-falls-into-zoo-exhibit-dies/|title=Child Mauled And Killed At Zoo|author=CBS News|accessdate=November 5, 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/11/07/14974451-zoo-officials-toddlers-death-in-pittsburgh-shows-no-zoo-is-100-percent-safe?lite Zoo officials: Toddler's death in Pittsburgh shows no zoo is 100 percent safe], NBC News, Andrew Mach, November 7, 2012.</ref> The dogs were sent to other North American zoos.
=== Coyotes === {{Main|Coyote attacks on humans}} [[Coyote]] attacks are uncommon and usually cause little harm but have become more frequent. This is especially true in California. Beginning 30 years prior to 2006 one hundred sixty took place mostly in the [[Los Angeles County]] region.<ref name="smithsonian200603">{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/City-Slinkers.html?c=y&story=fullstory|title=City Slinkers|publisher=Smithsonian|work=Smithsonian|date=March 2006|accessdate=14 June 2012|author=Dell'Amore, Christine}}</ref> 41 attacks occurred during 1988–1997, 48 attacks were verified from 1998 through 2003. The majority of these incidents occurred in Southern California.<ref name="AOH">{{cite web|title=Coyote Attacks: An Increasing Suburban Problem|url=http://www.co.san-diego.ca.us/awm/docs/coyoteattacks.pdf|accessdate=19 August 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926044522/http://www.co.san-diego.ca.us/awm/docs/coyoteattacks.pdf|archivedate=26 September 2007}}</ref> Some coyotes chase joggers and bicyclists, confront people walking their dogs, and stalk small children.<ref name="AOH" /> The coyote-wolf hybrids that roam [[Eastern Canada]] and parts of the [[Northeastern United States]] are known as [[eastern coyote]]s and [[coywolf|coywolves]].
* 1978 – a [[urban coyote|coyote]] attacked a five-year-old girl in [[Pasadena, California]] outside of her home. * 1979 – a coyote attacked a five-year-old girl in [[La Verne, California]]. Her father and a neighbor saved the child from being dragged off, but not before she had suffered deep bites on neck, head, and legs. * 1980 – a coyote in [[Agoura Hills, California]] grabbed a thirteen-month-old baby girl by the midsection and started dragging her off. The baby suffered puncture wounds but was saved by her mother. * 1981 - a three-year-old girl in [[Glendale, California]] was dragged by a coyote from the driveway of her home. Her father made an attempt to rescue her, but she later died from blood loss and a broken neck.<ref>http://www.desertusa.com/animals/coyotes-and-people.html</ref><ref>https://www.desertsun.com/story/life/home-garden/james-cornett/2014/08/23/james-cornett-coyotes-humans/14516033/</ref> * 1988 – an eight-year-old girl was bitten by a coyote while rollerskating in [[Oceanside, California]] when she fell to the ground. Two women chased the coyote away by throwing rocks at it. * 1992 – a coyote in [[San Clemente, California]] attacked a five-year-old girl biting her several times on her back. The girl climbed her swing set to escape, and her mother chased the coyote off. * 1995 – a five-year-old girl was knocked down twice by a coyote before being rescued by her mother in California's [[Griffith Park]]. * 1997 – a coyote attacked a two-year-old boy in [[Tucson, Arizona]]'s Wildlife Ridge Park, but did not damage his skin. The next day in that same park, a four-year-old boy was bitten and scratched and a twenty-two-month-old toddler was bitten around her right eye and required seven stitches for serious puncture injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.varmintal.com/attac.htm|title=Coyote Attacks on Children|publisher=}}</ref> * 1998 – a four-year-old boy who was bitten by a coyote while playing in the backyard of his home in [[Cape Cod]], Massachusetts. His mother tried force the coyote to go away, but it kept being around. A police officer responded to her telephone call to shoot and kill it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southcoasttoday.com/article/19980731/news/307319957|title=Coyote attacks boy on Cape Cod|first=The Associated|last=Press|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> * 2001 – a coyote seriously injured a seven-year-old girl in [[Northridge, Los Angeles|Northridge, California]], but was finally fought off by her mother. * 2003 – an [[eastern coyote]] bit an eighteen-year-old girl on the arm while she was hiking with her parents on the [[Skyline Trail (Cape Breton Highlands National Park)|Skyline Trail]] at [[Cape Breton Highlands National Park]] in Nova Scotia. * 2006 - two boys in [[Bellevue, Washington]] were bitten by a coyote when they were playing at home near their parents.<ref>http://www.seattletimes.com/html/eastsidenews/2002955935_coyote27e.html</ref> * 2007 – a coyote jumped out from a small line of bushes and bit a 5-year-old boy as he and his sister walked home from a neighbor's house in [[Middletown, New Jersey]]. He survived due to his sister's scream when she saw the incident, but needed 46 stitches in the back of his head and rabies shots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/18807033/ns/us_news-life/t/second-child-attacked-coyote-nj-town/#.V9hWmBQldz8|title=Second child attacked by coyote in N.J. town|date=22 May 2007|publisher=}}</ref> * 2008 – a nine-year-old boy was bitten by a coyote while snowboarding with his six-year-old brother on a golf course behind their house in [[Erie, Colorado]]. He used the snowboard to fend off the attack, but was bitten on the arm. A coyote in the area was then killed, but it wasn't clear if that was the same one that had bitten the boy, so he began [[Rabies#Treatment|a course of treatment for rabies]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/erie-boy-undergoing-rabies-treatment-after-coyote-attack|title=Erie Boy Undergoing Rabies Treatment After Coyote Attack|date=7 December 2008|publisher=}}</ref> * 2009 – a two-year-old girl in [[Port Coquitlam]], British Columbia was bitten by a coyote on a school playground. Adults near the area came to the little girl's aid and frightened the coyote away.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bc.ctvnews.ca/toddler-attacked-by-coyote-in-vancouver-suburb-1.412496|title=Toddler attacked by coyote in Vancouver suburb|publisher=}}</ref> A nineteen-year-old folk singer named [[Taylor Mitchell]] died after being attacked by two coyotes in Cape Breton Highlands National Park.<ref>http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/outposts/2009/10/musician-taylor-mitchell-dies.html</ref> * 2010 – a five-year-old girl was bitten by a coyote while she was walking with her parents and their dog in [[Vernon, British Columbia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/90401/coyote-attacks-5-year-old-okanagan-girl|title=Coyote attacks 5-year-old Okanagan girl|first=CHBC|last=News|publisher=}}</ref> An eastern coyote bit a sleeping sixteen-year-old girl on the head twice in her tent while she was camping with her parents at Cape Breton Highlands National Park in [[Ingonish]], Nova Scotia. She was taken to a hospital for stitches and treatment to prevent any rabies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capebretonpost.com/News/Local/2010-08-11/article-1665077/Campers-undeterred-by-coyote-attack/1|title=Campers undeterred by coyote attack|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> Two teenage Boy Scouts were bitten a coyote while they were sleeping outside their camping tent near Pole 3 in [[Port Aransas, Texas]]. These two boys were taken to a hospital in Corpus Christi for a treatment in rabies shots.<ref>12 August 2010 Port Aransas South Jetty News http://www.portasouthjetty.com/news/2010-08-12/Island_Life/Coyote_control.html</ref> * 2011 – a two-year-old girl was bitten on the neck by a coyote at a playground in [[Cave Creek, Arizona]]. She began a course of treatment for rabies after the adults saved her.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.azcentral.com/12news/news/articles/20110420cave-creek-toddler-bit-coyote-abrk.html|title=Coyote bites 2-year-old girl at Cave Creek Park|publisher=}}</ref> * 2012 – a fourteen-year-old boy was attacked by a coyote while riding on his dirt bike in [[Westmount, Nova Scotia]]. His [[body armor|body armour]], motocross pants and [[motocross boots|boots]] prevented his fatal injuries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/teen-attacked-by-coyote-kicked-it-in-the-ribs-1.1202669|title=Teen attacked by coyote kicked it in the ribs|publisher=}}</ref> * 2013 – a male camper in [[Kamloops]], [[British Columbia]] was assaulted by a coyote. The man was in a sleeping bag, but he was not inside a tent. The man drove himself to a hospital for his wounded stitches. Conservation officers subsequently hunted for the animal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Coyote 'plays around' with camper Visitor was outdoors in sleeping bag at Silver Sage Campground|url=http://www.kamloopsnews.ca/article/20130521/KAMLOOPS0101/130529986/-1/kamloops01/coyote-plays-around-with-camper|publisher=Kamloops The Daily News|accessdate=21 May 2013|date=21 May 2013|quote=the man was in a sleeping bag outside when the coyote attacked him at about 12:30 a.m. at the campground on Athabasca Street East}}</ref> A three-year-old boy in [[Chicago]], Illinois mistook a coyote for a domestic dog and was bitten in the face.<ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/15/emeil-hawkins-coyote_n_4283549.html</ref> * 2015 – a middle-aged man in [[Norwood, New Jersey]] was working in his garden when a coyote attacked him.<ref>{{cite web | title = Coyote euthanized after it attacks Saddle River man |publisher=NorthJersey.com | url = http://www.northjersey.com/news/coyote-euthanized-after-it-attacks-saddle-river-man-1.1303757 | accessdate = 2015-04-08 | first = JIM | last = NORMAN }}</ref> Two men were assaulted by a coyote in [[Groveland, Massachusetts]] outside both of their houses. One of them had his four-year-old daughter with him.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/coyote-attacks-residents-massachusetts-town-police-193045999.html Coyote attacks residents in Massachusetts town: police], Reuters, January 6, 2015</ref> * 2016 – a rabid coyote mauled a man who was walking in the woods with his two daughters in [[Lincoln, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtae.com/news/father-attacked-by-rabid-coyote-fights-back-and-survives/41124206|title=Father attacked by rabid coyote, fights back and survives|first=Bofta|last=Yimam|date=10 August 2016|publisher=}}</ref> A coyote bit two women and a domesticated dog in [[Wolcott, New York]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mpnnow.com/news/20161004/deputies-2-coyote-attacks-in-wayne-county|title=Deputies: 2 coyote attacks in Wayne County|first=News partner,|last=News10NBC|publisher=}}</ref> * 2017 – a sixty-six-year-old man who walked with two other adults and their domestic dogs along the [[Columbia Trail]] in [[Long Valley, New Jersey]] was mauled by a rabid coyote. The man fended it with a stick and police officers subsequently euthanized the animal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyrecord.com/story/news/local/morris-county/2017/01/11/man-fights-off-coyote-attack-long-valley-trail/96451632/|title=Man fights off coyote attack on Long Valley trail|publisher=}}</ref> A rabid coyote in [[Roswell, Georgia]] bit a man who was jogging in his neighborhood. While a neighbor called for the emergency number, the man pinned the animal to the ground for twenty minutes until paramedics came to his aid. He was sent to a hospital for rabies treatment.<ref>https://www.wsbtv.com/news/local/north-fulton-county/man-out-for-morning-jog-attacked-by-coyote/499161109</ref> Three coyotes in [[Alliston]], [[Ontario]] attacked a man who took his dog for a walk. The man's dog was able to fend them off. Neither the man nor his dog had any serious injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebarrieexaminer.com/2017/02/02/alliston-mans-dog-fends-off-attack|title=Coyote attack|first=|last=nurun.com|publisher=}}</ref> * 2018 – a man in [[Wake Forest, North Carolina]] was assaulted by a coyote while taking out the trash from his house. He recovered from his injuries.<ref>http://wwww.thelightnc.com/9702253/coyote-attacks-man-in-wake-forest/</ref> A five-year-old girl was bitten by a coyote while she was visiting a park with her mother and brother. Her mother and an off-duty police officer fought against the animal. Other police officers subsequently arrived and shot it. The girl was taken to a hospital for rabies treatment, stitches, and antibiotics.<ref>http://www.syracuse.com/state/index.ssf/2018/04/coyote_attacks_girl_mount_pleasant_westchester.html</ref><ref>http://www.fox5ny.com/news/coyote-attacks-5-year-old-girl-at-westchester-park</ref>
=== Dingo === In 1980, [[Lindy Chamberlain-Creighton]] was tried and convicted for the [[Death of Azaria Chamberlain|murder of her young daughter]], though Creighton claimed that dingos had taken her. Evidence later proved her account was true.
=== Dogs === {{Main|Dog bite}}{{See|Dog bite prevention}} Larger dogs are responsible for most animal bites overall and are the most common type of dog that bites with a fatal outcome. In the United States, there are 10 to 20 fatal human attacks annually. Not one breed is responsible for most of the bites, but at least 25 breeds of dogs were identified in the 238 fatalities in the past 25 years.
Most of the time, the victim is known by the owner of the dog. On fewer occasions, the bites suffered by the victim are from their own dog. Only about ten percent of dog bites are from strays.<ref name=Cherry2014 /> The National Health and Human Services agency in the United States reports that 9.9% of deaths caused by animals were from dogs.<ref>Langley, p.10</ref>
=== Foxes === {{See also|Fox attack}}
Unprovoked fox attacks are occasionally reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/london/3083070.stm|title=BBC NEWS – UK – England – London – Girl bitten by fox|website=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/7813635/I-was-bitten-by-a-fox-too-says-nine-year-old-girl.html|title=I was bitten by a fox too, says nine year-old girl|publisher=}}</ref> Victims were often children, and it can happen if there were gaps in homes through which foxes could pass.<ref name="EveningStandard2018">{{cite news |authors=Dunne, J.; Moore-Bridger, B.; Powell, T. |title=Woman mauled in bed by fox in Clapham flat: I'm traumatised and feared I would contract rabies |publisher=The [[Evening Standard]] |location=[[London]] |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/woman-mauled-in-bed-by-fox-im-traumatised-and-fear-i-would-contract-rabies-a3868586.html |date=2018-06-21 |access-date=2018-06-22}}</ref>
=== Wolves === {{Main|Wolf attacks on humans}} * [[Kirov wolf attacks]] * [[Wolf of Ansbach]] * [[Wolf of Gysinge]] * [[Wolf of Sarlat]] * [[Wolf of Soissons]] * [[Wolves of Ashta]] * [[Wolves of Hazaribagh]] * [[Wolves of Périgord]] * [[Wolves of Turku]]
== Crocodilians ==
=== [[Alligators]] === {{Main|List of fatal alligator attacks in the United States by decade}} Alligators are capable of killing humans but fatal attacks are fairly rare and uncommon. Mistaken identity leading to an attack is always possible, especially in or near cloudy waters. American alligators are often less aggressive towards humans than larger crocodile species, a few of which (mainly the Nile and Saltwater crocodiles) may prey on humans with some regularity. American alligator bites are serious injuries due to the reptile's sheer bite force and risk of infection. Even with medical treatment, an American alligator bite may still result in a fatal infection. As human populations increase, and as they build houses in low-lying areas or fish or hunt near water, incidents are inevitable where American alligators intrude, or at least appear to intrude, on human life. Since 1948, 257 documented attacks on humans in Florida (about five incidents per year) have been reported, of which an estimated 23 resulted in death. Only nine fatal attacks occurred in the United States throughout the 1970s–1990s, but American alligators killed 12 people between 2001 and 2007. In May 2006, American alligators killed three Floridians in less than a week. There have been at least 28 fatal attacks by American alligators in the United States since 1970. In contrast, alligator attacks are rare because they target prey animals that are smaller than adult humans. Their normal prey includes fish, birds, other reptiles and small mammals. Unfortunately, children are about the same size as these animals, so they can become targets.
=== Crocodiles === {{Main|Crocodile attack}} [[Crocodile]] attacks often result in fatalities.<ref name=e298>Egerton, p. 298.</ref> Estimates of deaths due to attacks by the [[Nile crocodile]] is estimated to be hundreds and possibly thousands yearly.<ref>Wood, The Guinness Book of Animal Facts and Feats. Sterling Pub Co Inc (1983), {{ISBN|978-0-85112-235-9}}</ref><ref name=AusCrocAttack>{{cite journal|last=Caldicott|first=David G.E.|author2=Croser, David|author3=Manolis, Charlie|author4=Webb, Grahame|author5=Britton, Adam|title=Crocodile Attack in Australia: An Analysis of Its Incidence and Review of the Pathology and Management of Crocodilian Attacks in General|journal=Wilderness & Environmental Medicine|date=1 September 2005|volume=16|issue=3|pages=143–159|doi=10.1580/1080-6032(2005)16[143:CAIAAA]2.0.CO;2|url=http://www.wemjournal.org/article/S1080-6032%2805%2970380-X/fulltext|accessdate=3 February 2013|pmid=16209470}}</ref> Attacks by Nile crocodiles range from 275 to 745 per year. 63% of these are fatal. Only 30 attacks have been recorded per year by [[saltwater crocodile]]s, of which 50% are fatal. Fatal attacks are typically made by very large crocodiles. The Nile crocodile is considered to be the most prolific [[predator]] of humans among wild animals at this time.<ref name=iucncsg>{{cite web|title=Crocodilian Attacks|url=http://www.iucncsg.org/pages/Crocodilian-Attacks.html|publisher=IUCN Crocodile Specialist Group (iucncsg.org)|accessdate=3 February 2013}}</ref> Crocodile tracking technology is currently under development that would prevent attacks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/sci-tech/tracking-crocodile-movements-could-reduce-attacks-on-humans-researchers-say-20150123-12wump.html|title=Tracking crocodile movements could reduce attacks on humans, researchers say|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> *Isabel von Jordan, 23, was killed by a saltwater crocodile in [[Kakadu National Park]], Australia while swimming in the billabong with her sister Valerie and a few other backpackers.<ref>{{cite book | author=Wendy Lewis | title=See Australia and Die | publisher=New Holland | year=2007 | isbn=978-1-74110-583-4 }}</ref><ref name="aus">[http://www.smh.com.au/national/recent-crocodile-deaths-in-australia-20090411-a3b2.html Recent crocodile deaths in Australia]. Smh.com.au (2009-04-11). Retrieved on 2011-03-19.</ref> *Jacques van der Sandt, 29, was killed by a crocodile on a South African golf course while trying to recover a missing ball. The crocodile grabbed him and pulled him underwater.<ref name="oddee.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.oddee.com/item_99349.aspx|title=8 Deadly Wild Animal Attacks – ODDEE|date=8 June 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2861011/Horror-golf-course-player-killed-crocodile-Man-dragged-dam-called-Lake-Panic-retrieving-balls-Kruger-Park.html|title=Horror on the golf course as player is killed by a crocodile|publisher=}}</ref>
== Deer == When a deer attacks, they use their antlers and hooves. They can cause severe injuries and fatalities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reference.com/pets-animals/deer-attack-people-a4f9e9e72b648234|title=Do deer attack people?|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> People are more likely to die from a deer attack than they are from a wolf attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.quora.com/Are-you-more-likely-to-be-killed-by-a-deer-or-by-a-wolf|title=Are you more likely to be killed by a deer or by a wolf? - Quora|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref>
=== Elk === *2011 – a woman in Arizona was trampled in her front yard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs5az.com/story/14986780/arizona-woman-attacked-by-elk|title=Arizona woman attacked by elk|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> *2012 – a woman was attacked and trampled outside her apartment by an elk.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kdvr.com/2012/05/29/estes-park-woman-trampled-by-elk/|title=Estes Park woman seriously injured in elk attack|date=29 May 2012|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref>
=== Moose === {{Main|Moose attacks}} [[File:Norwegian-road-sign-146.1.svg| thumb|150px | A warning to watch for moose]] [[Moose]] attacks occur with some frequency and they have been found to attack more often than grizzly bears.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glacier-national-park-travel-guide.com/moose-attack.html|title=Moose Attack Survival Skills – Preventing & Surviving Moose Attacks|date=3 March 2009|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref><ref name = Alaska2011 />
*2006 – a man from Grand Lake, Colorado was killed by a moose.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/man-attacked-by-moose-dies|title=Man Attacked By Moose Dies|date=6 April 2006|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> *2006 – a man was attacked in [[Grand Lake, Colorado]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://scicolorado.org/moose-attacks-grand-lake-man/|title=Moose Attacks Grand Lake Man » Safari Club International of Colorado|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> * 2008 – a Swedish woman was killed by a moose during an evening walk.<ref>''[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/6678397/Sweden-woman-murdered-by-elk-not-husband.html]''</ref> * 2011 – a six-year-old boy was attacked and became unconscious after the attack.<ref name = Alaska2011 /> * 2011 – an Alaskan girl was attacked while riding her bike.<ref name = Alaska2011 /> * 2011 – An Alaskan woman was attacked while clearing brush on her property.<ref name = Alaska2011>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/caution-warned-after-alaska-moose-attacks/|title=Caution warned after Alaska moose attacks|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> * 2012 – a Vermont man woke to find a moose walking on his car.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/videos/watch-deranged-moose-attacks-vt-man/|title=Watch: Deranged moose attacks Vt. man|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> *2012 – a Canadian man ended up in the intensive care unit after being attacked.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frontiersman.com/news/moose-attack-hospitalizes-willow-man/article_80c0c50c-43df-11e1-92d1-0019bb2963f4.html|title=Moose attack hospitalizes Willow man|first=HEATHER A. RESZ|last=Frontiersman.com|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> * 2014 – in the city of [[Black Hawk, Colorado]] two women were walking their dogs and were injured from an attacking moose.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/05/20/us/colorado-moose-attack/index.html|title=Colorado moose attack injures 2 women – CNN.com|first=By Ed Payne|last=CNN|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> * 2014 – two hikers were attacked in Colorado.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/science/2014/05/20/moose-attacks-two-hikers-in-colorado.html|title=Moose attacks two hikers in Colorado|date=20 May 2014|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> * 2014 – a woman walking down a sidewalk in Smithers, British Columbia was attacked from behind by a moose.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/moose-attack-caught-on-camera-in-smithers-b-c-1.2536471|title=Moose attack caught on camera in Smithers, B.C.|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> * 2017 – Utah hikers, [[Backpacking (wilderness)|backpackers]], and [[skiing|skiers]] were attacked multiple times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox13now.com/2017/01/30/moose-attack-friday-may-have-been-cause-of-saturday-moose-attack/|title=Moose attack Friday may have been cause of Saturday moose attack|date=31 January 2017|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> *2017 – snowboarders near Aspen, Colorado were attacked shortly after being caught in an avalanche. They were able to escape the avalanche with some injuries but then were attacked by a moose.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2017/02/15/snowboarders-avalanche-moose-attack-aspen/|title=Snowboarders caught in avalanche, fight off moose near Aspen – The Denver Post|first=The Aspen|last=Times|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref>
=== White-tailed and mule deer === *2003 – a man in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. was injured and subsequently died from antler wounds to the face when he was picking tomatoes in his garden.<ref name = deer2003>{{cite web|last=Kasindorf |first=Martin |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2005-12-01-deer-attacks_x.htm |title=USATODAY.com – Deer attacks: Nature, civilization lock horns |publisher=Usatoday30.usatoday.com |date=2005-12-01 |accessdate=2017-04-10}}</ref> *2005 – a woman from Clearlake, California received head injuries outside her home. Her husband was also injured when he tried to rescue his wife.<ref name = deer2003 /> *2017 – a woman was attacked in Preston, Idaho.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rd.com/true-stories/survival/teen-saves-others-from-deer-attack/|title=Teen Saves Others from Deer Attack Using a Hammer - Reader's Digest|date=17 January 2014|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref> *2017 – a deer attacked students in Southern Illinois University at Carbondale and other people in the area in a series of attacks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/fourth-deer-attack-siu-carbondale-deer-killed-time#stream/0|title=Fourth deer attack at SIU-Carbondale; deer killed this time|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2017}}</ref>
== Elephants == Wild [[elephant]]s have attacked, harmed and killed people.<ref>{{cite web|title=British teacher gored by elephant on South African safari|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/southafrica/10572541/British-teacher-gored-by-elephant-on-South-African-safari.html|accessdate=25 March 2015|publisher=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Elephants carry out 'revenge' attacks on villages after one of their herd was hit and killed by a train|publisher=Daily Mail Online|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2388182/Elephants-carrying-revenge-attacks-village-herd-hit-killed-train.html|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> [[Jacky Boxberger]], an Olympic athlete, [[Bùi Thị Xuân]], a Vietnamese woman general and [[Allen Campbell]], a professional elephant [[Animal training|trainer]] were attacked and killed by [[Asian elephant]]s. Elephants have attacked people in villages in India.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://video.foxnews.com/v/2676636651001/deadly-herd-of-elephants-attacks-village-in-india/?#sp=show-clips|title=Deadly herd of elephants attacks village in India|accessdate=25 March 2015|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.manoramaonline.com/news/nation/2017/06/02/four-trampled-to-death-by-elephant-in-city-outskirts.html|title=Wild elephant enters house, tramples 4 to death on the outskirts of Coimbatore|publisher=}}</ref>
In a very rare case, according to The Huffington Post, a 7-year old girl died on Tuesday, July 27, 2016, after an elephant at the Rabat-Temara Zoo accidentally threw a stone at her.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/elephant-kills-schoolgirl-by-flinging-a-rock-at-her-head-in-moroccan-zoo_uk_579a0ae6e4b02508de486774|title=Elephant Kills Schoolgirl By Flinging A Rock At Her Head In Moroccan Zoo|last=Nelson|first=Sara C|date=July 28, 2016}}</ref>
Ian Gibson, 55 and a pro big game hunter, was charged by an elephant he had been tracking and trampled to death.<ref name="oddee.com" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/professional-big-game-hunter-ian-gibson-crushed-to-death-by-elephant-during-hunt-10186864.html|title=Professional big game hunter crushed to death by elephant he was|date=18 April 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
== [[Felid]]s ==
=== Cheetahs === A boy vacationing in South Africa was bitten by a cheetah.<ref name="news1">{{cite web|url=http://traveller24.news24.com/Explore/Green/cheetah-attacks-kiwi-boy-in-sa-when-will-we-put-a-stop-to-wildlife-petting-20170318 |title=Cheetah attacks Kiwi boy in SA: When will we put a stop to wildlife petting? | Traveller24 |publisher=Traveller24.news24.com |date=2017-03-18 |accessdate=2017-04-10}}</ref>
=== Cougars === {{See also|List of fatal cougar attacks in North America}} In 2005, a British man was attacked by what he described as a [[black panther]].<ref>{{cite news| title = 'Big cat' attacks man in garden | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/london/4370893.stm | accessdate = 2015-12-03 | date = 22 March 2005| publisher = BBC }}</ref>
=== House cats === {{Main|Cat bite}} Though very rare, cats have attacked and killed people.<ref>{{cite web| title = Brett Nash cat electrocution case: Can a cat kill you?| url = http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/explainer/2012/12/brett_nash_cat_electrocution_case_can_a_cat_kill_you.html| accessdate = 2017-02-28}}</ref> Cat bites may be under reported.<ref>{{cite web | title = Cat bites more prone to infect, but reported less than dog bites in Longmont, Boulder | publisher = Times-Call Local News | date = 2017-02-17 | accessdate = 2017-02-28 | url = http://www.timescall.com/longmont-local-news/ci_30803131/cat-bites-more-prone-infect-but-reported-less | first = Amelia | last = Arvesen }}</ref> Cats also can attack other animals and cause significant injuries.<ref>{{cite web | date = 2016-08-18 | access-date = 2017-02-28 | title = A Ferocious Cat Attacked a Woman and 7 Pitbulls | publisher = Fox News Insider | url = http://insider.foxnews.com/2016/08/18/cat-attacks-7-pitbulls-who-didnt-fight-back }}</ref>
=== Jaguars === A jaguar at the [[John Ball Zoological Garden|John Ball Zoo]] fatally mauled a pregnant employee on December 9, 1985.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Archives/1985/12/13/Cage-door-blamed-in-fatal-jaguar-attack/1337503298000/|title=Cage door blamed in fatal jaguar attack|publisher=}}</ref> A jaguar at the [[Denver Zoo]] killed a young female employee on February 24, 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/19077546/ns/us_news-life/t/fatal-jaguar-attack-tragic-accident-not-crime/#.WKu0iRQldz8|title=Fatal jaguar attack 'a tragic accident,' not crime|date=6 June 2007|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/jaguar-mauls-kills-zookeeper-at-denver-zoo|title=Jaguar Mauls, Kills Zookeeper At Denver Zoo|date=24 February 2007|publisher=}}</ref> A jaguar in [[Belize]] killed a young American man on October 25, 2010. It escaped after a tree fell on its cage during Hurricane Richard one night earlier.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amandala.com.bz/news/tamed-jaguar-max-escapes-during-hurricane-and-kills-man/|title=Tamed jaguar, Max, escapes during hurricane and kills man – Amandala Newspaper|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/jaguar-sprung-in-belize-hurricane-kills-us-man/|title=Jaguar Sprung in Belize Hurricane Kills U.S. Man|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Leopards === {{Main|Leopard attack}} [[Leopard]] attacks remain a danger in some areas.<ref name="ReferenceA">Nowak, Ronald M; and Paradiso, John L. Walker's Mammals of the World. 4th ed. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press; 1983. p1090</ref> One leopard in India killed over 200 people.<ref name="ReferenceA" /> Leopard attacks usually occur at night. *A wild leopard wandered into an Indian village and attacked at least 11 people in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://list25.com/25-worst-animal-attacks-in-recent-memory/2/|title=25 Worst Animal Attacks In Recent Memory|date=28 March 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/india/8651282/Leopard-mauls-11-in-Indian-village.html|title=Leopard mauls 11 in Indian village|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Lions === {{Main|Lion#Man-eating}} [[Lion]]s enter areas occupied by humans.<ref name="GC" /> Lion attacks in [[Tanzania]] increased from 1990 to 2005. At least 563 villagers were attacked and many devoured over this period. Researchers argue that [[conservation movement|conservation]] policy contributes directly to human deaths. Lions have taken people from the center of large villages. Estimates stand at 550–700 people attacked by lions every year.<ref name="Packer05">{{cite journal|last=Packer|first=C.|author2=Ikanda, D.|author3=Kissui, B.|author4=Kushnir, H.|date=August 2005|title=Conservation biology: lion attacks on humans in Tanzania|journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]|volume=436|issue=7053|pages=927–928|doi=10.1038/436927a|pmid=16107828}}</ref> *On July 24, 1976 at [[Kings Island]], a lion mauled a 20-year-old park employee to death. His body was found 15 to 20 feet from his vehicle, which was protected by iron bars, in a section of the park's 1000-acre wildlife preserve where about 50 lions lived. The ranger had a history of violating park rules. Investigators believed the ranger left the vehicle to relieve himself. *On May 26, 1982 at Kings Island, a lion attacked a 34-year-old park employee who was cleaning in the area. After climbing to a rooftop, he was rescued and taken to a hospital where he was treated for a punctured trachea and other cuts. *[[Katherine Chappell]], a 29 year old was killed by a lion while on a safari vacation in South Africa. It had jumped through an open window in a vehicle and killed her on June 1, 2015.<ref name="oddee.com" />
=== Tigers === {{Main|Tiger attack}} [[Tiger]]s kill more people than any other [[big cat]], and tigers have been responsible for more human deaths through direct attack than any other wild mammal.<ref name="Nowak, Ronald M 1983">Nowak, Ronald M; and Paradiso, John L. Walker's Mammals of the World. 4th ed. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press; 1983. p1088</ref> One hundred and twenty-nine people were [[tiger attacks in the Sundarbans|killed by tigers in the Sundarbans]] from 1969–71.<ref name="Nowak, Ronald M 1983" /><ref name="GC">{{cite book|author=John Seidensticker and Susan Lumpkin|url=|title=Great Cats|year=1991|page=240|isbn=0-87857-965-6}}</ref> The [[Sundarbans]] are occupied by 600 [[Bengal tiger]]s<ref name="Maneaters, tiger and lion">{{cite web|url=http://www.lairweb.org.nz/tiger/maneating7.html|title=Man-eaters-The tiger and lion, attacks on humans|author=Loadstar|work=lairweb.org.nz}}</ref> who before modern times used to "regularly kill fifty or sixty people a year". Attacks continue to increase.<ref name="Maneaters">{{cite web|title=Maneaters: The Sundarbans|url=http://www.lairweb.org.nz/tiger/maneating7.html|publisher=lairweb|accessdate=11 December 2013}}</ref><ref name=tiger_2008>{{cite news|title=Tiger attacks on rise in Indian Sundarbans|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-tiger-attacks-on-rise-in-indian-sundarbans-1180734|accessdate=11 March 2014|newspaper=[[DNA India]]|date=30 July 2008|agency=[[Indo-Asian News Service]]}}</ref> *Maqsood, a 22 year old man who had a fascination with tigers, was killed on September 24, 2014, in New Delhi when he entered a tiger's enclosure. He is believed to have been intoxicated at the time.<ref name="oddee.com" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/Maqsoods-obsession-with-tigers-led-to-his-death/articleshow/43358473.cms|title=Maqsood's obsession with tigers led to his death – Times of India|publisher=}}</ref>
==== Well-known and documented tigers ==== * [[Tigers of Chowgarh]] (1925–30) * [[Tiger of Mundachipallam]] * [[Tiger of Segur]] * [[Champawat Tiger|Tigress of Champawat]] (killed in 1907) * [[Tigress of Jowlagiri]]
== Fish == In 2016, [[Piranha]] attacked a group of swimmers in Rio de Janeiro.{{Citation needed|reason=Previously had been cited to reference 78, which has zero mention of any such attack.|date=May 2017}}
A [[Kali River goonch attacks|Goonch fish]] in India was thought to have killed many people <ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/story/640061/corpse-eating-mutant-fish-caught|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131030194722/http://news.sky.com/story/640061/corpse-eating-mutant-fish-caught|dead-url=yes|archive-date=30 October 2013|title=Corpse-Eating Mutant Fish Caught|date=30 October 2013|publisher=}}</ref>
== Hippopotamus == [[File:Mereruka Hippo relief.jpg|thumb|Egyptian tomb relief showing a hippopotamus attacking a Nile crocodile]] The [[hippopotamus]] is often cited as the most dangerous large animal in the world, killing an estimated 500 people a year in Africa.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-36320744|title=What are the world's deadliest animals?|date=2016-06-15|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-02-28|language=en-GB}}</ref> However, there are no academic or formal studies providing support for this claim, and its continued persistence seems to be dependent on the repetition of a well established folk narrative as opposed to actual reports or numbers.
== Hyenas == Attacks on humans by [[spotted hyena]]s are underreported.<ref name="SGDRN">Begg, Colleen, Begg, Kieth & Muemedi, Oscar (2007) ''[http://www.selous-niassa-corridor.org/fileadmin/publications/2007-Human-Carnivore_Crocodile_Conflict_-NNR.pdf Preliminary data on human – carnivore conflict in Niassa National Reserve, Mozambique, particularly fatalities due to lion, spotted hyaena and crocodile]'', SGDRN (Sociedade para a Gestão e Desenvolvimento da Reserva do Niassa Moçambique)</ref> A pair of hyenas were responsible for killing 27 people in [[Mulanje]], [[Malawi]] in 1962.<ref name="maneat">Kruuk, Hans (2002) ''Hunter and hunted: relationships between carnivores and people'' Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-89109-4}}</ref> In 1910 spotted hyenas were observed to kill sufferers of [[African sleeping sickness]] as they slept outside in camps.<ref>Roosevelt, Theodore (1910) ''African Game Trails: An Account of the African Wanderings of an American Hunter, Naturalist'', New York, C. Scribner's sons</ref>
== Komodo dragons == [[File:KomodoDragon.jpg|thumb|Komodo Dragon]] A man was bitten and subsequently lost his big toe to a [[Komodo dragon]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Cagle|first=Jess|url=http://www.time.com/time/sampler/article/0,8599,133163,00.html|title=Transcript: Sharon Stone vs. the Komodo Dragon|publisher=TIME|date=23 June 2001|accessdate=12 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1382755.stm|title=Lizard bites Sharon Stone's husband|publisher=BBC News|date=11 June 2001|accessdate=12 February 2010}}</ref> Attacks occur infrequently in Indonesia.<ref>Markus Makur, '[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/10/13/komodo-dragon-bites-elderly-woman-rinca-island.html Giant lizard attack: Komodo dragon bites elderly woman on Rinca island'], ''The Jakarta Post'', 13 October 2012.
