[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/02/07/2-hospitalized-indonesia-after-komodo-attack.html 2 hospitalized in Indonesia after Komodo attack'], ''The Jakarta Post'', 7 February 2013.</ref> *2007 – an eight-year-old boy was killed by a Komodo dragon on Komodo Island<ref name = Smithsonian>{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/the-most-infamous-komodo-dragon-attacks-of-the-past-10-years-5831048/ |title=The Most Infamous Komodo Dragon Attacks of the Past 10 Years | Science | Smithsonian |publisher=Smithsonianmag.com |date=2013-01-24 |accessdate=2017-04-10}}</ref> *2008 – 2008, a group of SCUBA divers washed up on Rinca Island which is populated by 1,300 of the lizards and were attacked repeatedly while awaiting rescue.<ref name = Smithsonian />
== Primates == Some studies cite encroachment as the cause of attacks by primates resulting in injuries and deaths to humans. Many African states offer government sponsored insurance programs that will dispense payments to those who are attacked (unprovoked) or killed by large primates. In some instances "...local people feel that the needs or values of wildlife are given priority over their own needs..." Gorillas often raid the crops of some villages. Villagers are sometimes hurt or killed defending their crops against gorillas. Women and children are more likely to be attacked by a raiding gorilla than men.<ref>http://pubs.iied.org/pdfs/G03725.pdf</ref> Domestic animals are also attacked by gorillas.<ref>https://portals.iucn.org/library/efiles/documents/ssc-op-037.pdf</ref>
=== Chimpanzees === {{Main|Common chimpanzee#Attacks}} Generally, chimpanzees are aggressive in the wild. Males are more aggressive than females. Male chimpanzees will attack other chimpanzees sometimes engaging in 'warfare'. They are capable of causing serious injury and death.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/why-would-a-chimpanzee-at/|title=Why would a chimpanzee attack a human?|first=Katherine|last=Harmon|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2009 in Stamford, Connecticut, [[Travis (chimpanzee)|Travis]] attacked a 55-year-old woman named Charla Nash, ripping her face and hands off.
In 2012, villagers living near [[Virunga National Park]] were attacked by [[common chimpanzee]]s. One girl was killed.<ref>{{cite web | title = Amid armed conflict, Congolese villagers face chimpanzee attacks | publisher=The FRANCE 24 Observers |date=26 September 2012 | url = http://observers.france24.com/content/20120926-midst-armed-conflict-congolese-villagers-chimpanzee-attacks-rebels-tong-north-kivu-endangered-species-tongo | accessdate = 2015-04-06 }}</ref>
=== Macaque === A six-week-old infant was killed in her home while sleeping by a macaque that entered through the window. The animal had escaped from a zoo.<ref>{{cite web | title = 6-week-old baby killed by monkey that escaped from private zoo in Crimea | publisher=Daily Mail Online | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2700023/Six-week-old-baby-killed-monkey-home-animal-escaped-nearby-private-zoo-tore-child-s-head-pieces-Crimea.html | accessdate = 2015-12-15 }}</ref>
== Rhinoceros == In May 2003, Mark Crozier and his brother Sean were on a game walk with a group of safari hikers led by two armed rangers when a [[south-central black rhinoceros|black rhinoceros]] attacked them during their walk at [[Hluhluwe–Imfolozi Park]] in [[South Africa]]. Two game rangers fired warning shots at the rhinoceros while the tourists hid in a dense bush. Both of the Crozier brothers had severe wounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/rogue-rhino-attacks-brothers-in-game-reserve-105857|title=Rogue rhino attacks brothers in game reserve – IOL|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.sosrhino.org/news/rhinonews/rhinonews050803.php]{{dead link|date=April 2017}}</ref>
On April 15, 2004, a [[southern white rhinoceros|white rhinoceros]] at [[Kruger National Park]] charged and lifted up safari guide Elias Chauke with its horn before he was able to pull his trigger at it. His colleague, Dumisani Zwane, hit the rhinoceros as it passed him, making it drop Chauke. Meanwhile another black rhinoceros charged at the group of five tourists, injuring one man, Botha from Vereeniging, in the buttocks and the back.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/rhinos-attack-hiking-parties-in-kruger-park-210730|title=Rhinos attack hiking parties in Kruger Park – IOL|publisher=}}</ref>
A black rhinoceros gored a female wildlife researcher in a holding pen at Hluhluwe–Imfolozi on September 21, 2004. A month later, another black rhinoceros struck a young male Zululand contractor in the right side of the chest and he fell screaming to the ground to attract the attention of his colleagues.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/second-person-gored-by-rhino-at-umfolozi-223471|title=Second person gored by rhino at Umfolozi – IOL|publisher=}}</ref>
== Seals and sea lions == {{see also|Walrus attack}} Seal and sea lion attacks are rare on humans, but coming to close to them can be very unsafe. Many seals and sea lions attack to protect themselves or their young because they feel threatened even if the humans around them have no intention of harming them. Human presence and human recreational activities can cause sea lions to engage in violent and aggressive actions. When humans come closer than 15 meters of a sea lion, the sea lions' vigilance increases because of the disturbance of humans. These disturbances can potentially cause sea lions to have psychological stress responses that cause the sea lions to retreat, sometimes even abandon their locations, and decreases the amount of time sea lions spend hauling out.
* 1985 – Gareth Wood was bitten twice on his leg by a leopard seal. * 2003 – Kirsty Brown was dragged underwater by a leopard seal. * 2007 – a sea lion attacks a 13-year-old-girl surfing behind a speedboat in Australia. The sea lion appeared to be preparing for a second attack when the girl was rescued. An Australian marine biologist suggested that the sea lion may have viewed the girl "like a rag doll toy" to be played with. * 2015 – a sea lion attacks a 62-year-old man who was boating with his wife in San Diego. The attack left the man with a punctured bone. * 2017 – a sea lion dragged a small girl by her dress into the water while she was sitting on a pier side around the time tourists in British Columbia were illegally feeding the sea lions. She was pulled out of the water with minor injuries and received antibiotic prophylactic treatment for seal finger infection from the superficial bite injury.
== Sharks == {{Main|Shark attack}} Out of the four hundred eighty [[List of sharks|shark species]], only three are responsible for the majority of fatal, unprovoked attacks on humans: the [[great white shark|great white]], [[tiger shark|tiger]] and [[bull shark|bull]].<ref name="isaf">ISAF [http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/sharks/statistics/species3.htm Statistics on Attacking Species of Shark]</ref> The [[oceanic whitetip shark|oceanic whitetip]] has likely killed castaways, not recorded in the statistics.<ref name="howstuffdangerous4">{{cite web|last=Edmonds |first=Molly |url=http://animals.howstuffworks.com/fish/most-dangerous-shark2.htm |title=HowStuffWorks "Dangerous Shark 4: Oceanic Whitetip Shark" |publisher=Animals.howstuffworks.com |date= |accessdate=23 September 2010}}</ref>
== Snakes == {{further|List of fatal snake bites in the United States}}
The World Health Organization has determined that up to five million people get bitten by snakes yearly with 94,000 to 125,000 deaths. Other consequences include infection, tetanus, scarring, psychoses, and 400,000 amputations. Other severe health consequences occur such as infection, tetanus, scarring, contractures, and psychological sequelae. Snake bites occur most frequently in South-East Asia and Africa among those who live in less affluent areas, farming communities.<ref name= WHObites /> The National Health and Human Services agency in the United States reported 66 fatalities between 1979 and 1990 from snakes.<ref name="Langley, p.9">Langley, p.9</ref>
=== Pythons === Species of [[python (genus)|python]] have attacked people and caused human fatalities. These include: * Early 19th century – Two people in Indonesia<ref name="Kop27">{{aut|Kopstein, F.}} (1927): Over het verslinden van menschen door ''Python reticulatus'' ["On the swallowing of humans by ''P. reticulatus''"]. ''Tropische Natuur'' '''4''': 65–67. [Article in Dutch]</ref> * 1910 or 1927 – a man on a hunting trip from [[Burma]].<ref name="Bru98">Bruno, Silvio (1998): [https://web.archive.org/web/20070228013241/http://www.pna.it/Site_old/criptozoologia/serpenti.htm I serpenti giganti] ["The giant snakes"]. ''Criptozoologia'' '''4''': 16–29. (in Italian) Accessed 22 March 2015</ref> * 1932 – a Filipino teenager was consumed by his pet.<ref name="Mur97">Kobis I. 1995. [http://arachnophiliac.info/burrow/news/giant_python_killed.htm Giant python killed after trying to swallow man]. The Star (Malaysian English newspaper), Accessed 22 March 2015.</ref> * 1995 – a 29-year-old tapper from southern Malaysia<ref name="Mur97" /> * 2008 – a 25-year-old woman.<ref name="UPI">[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2008/10/23/Woman_killed_by_pet_13-foot_python/UPI-21431224801360/ Woman killed by pet 13-foot python] at [http://www.upi.com/ UPI]. Accessed 22 March 2015.</ref> * 2009, a 3-year-old [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] boy was attacked but rescued before being [[asphyxiated]].<ref name="Las Vegas Sun">[http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2009/jan/22/python-vs-angry-mom-knife/ In Las Vegas, python vs. angry mom with a knife] at [http://www.lasvegassun.com/ Las Vegas Sun]. Accessed 22 March 2015.</ref> * 2009, a two-year-old [[Orlando]] area girl was killed<ref>https://abcnews.go.com/US/python-owners-12-years-girls-strangle-death/story?id=14373295</ref>
==== African Rock pythons ==== An [[African rock python]] [[2013 New Brunswick python attack|allegedly killed two boys]] in [[Campbellton, New Brunswick]] in 2013.<ref name=NatGeo>Than, K., "[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/08/130806-python-strangles-kids-canada-snakes/ Strangulation of Sleeping Boys Puts Spotlight on Pythons]", ''[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic Daily News]]'', 6 August 2013.</ref>
== Squirrels == {{See|Electrical disruptions caused by squirrels}} Squirrels will attack unprovoked,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/true-crime/wp/2016/11/04/its-jumping-on-people-and-biting-them-squirrel-attack-leaves-3-injured-at-retirement-home/|title=‘It’s jumping on people and biting them’: Squirrel attack leaves 3 injured at retirement home|first=|last=https://www.facebook.com/lindseybever|website=Washington Post}}</ref> sometimes even in packs.<ref name="lomography.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.lomography.com/magazine/63939-angriff-der-eichhrnchen-st-james-park-london|title=Lomography – Angriff der Eichhörnchen (St. James Park, London)|publisher=|accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref>
*2002 – A grandfather killed a squirrel that attacked his grand-daughter. Others in the village were afraid to let their children outdoors to play.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://rt4rf9qn2y.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fsummon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=Grandfather+kills+belligerent+squirrel.+%28Bizarre%29&rft.jtitle=Vietnam+Investment+Review&rft.date=2002-11-18&rft.pub=Vietnam+Investment+Review+Ltd&rft.issn=1021-318X&rft.spage=SS11&rft.externalDBID=XI7&rft.externalDocID=A95262787&paramdict=en-US | title=Grandfather kills belligerent squirrel | publisher = Vietnam Investment Review | date = 18 Nov 2002 | accessdate = 6 June 2017}}</ref> * In 2016, a squirrel attacked a group of people in Deltona, Florida in a Senior Care facility. Three people were injured by the squirrel and required medical care.<ref name="Hayes">{{cite web|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/breaking-news/os-squirrel-attack-volusia-senior-home-20161103-story.html|title=Squirrel attacks seniors in retirement community — worker calls 911 for help|first=Christal|last=Hayes|publisher=|accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref> * A couple in San Francisco suffered an attack by a squirrel.<ref name="sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com">{{cite web|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2015/12/04/novato-couple-recount-terrifying-squirrel-attack/|title=Novato Couple Recount Terrifying Squirrel Attack|publisher=}}</ref> * An outspoken critic of aggressive squirrels in New York city was attacked by a squirrel himself while riding his bicycle.<ref name="washingtonpost.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/the-bushy-tailed-nut-loving-menace-coming-after-americas-power-grid/2015/12/25/d4b4c2b6-a8db-11e5-9b92-dea7cd4b1a4d_story.html|title=The bushy-tailed, nut-loving menace coming after America’s power grid|website=Washington Post}}</ref> * A pet squirrel scared off a burglar that entered his owner's home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesunion.com/news/crime/article/Pet-squirrel-that-foiled-Idaho-home-burglary-11230626.php|title=Pet squirrel that foiled Idaho home burglary returns to wild|publisher=}}</ref> * Other instances of squirrel attacks have occurred.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/true-crime/wp/2016/11/04/its-jumping-on-people-and-biting-them-squirrel-attack-leaves-3-injured-at-retirement-home/|title=‘It’s jumping on people and biting them’: Squirrel attack leaves 3 injured at retirement home|first=Lindsey|last=Bever|website=Washington Post|accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref name="Hayes"/><ref name="lomography.com"/><ref name="sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com"/><ref name="washingtonpost.com"/>
== Stingrays == {{main|Stingray injury}} Stingray injuries are caused by the [[venom]]ous tail spines, stingers or [[dermal denticle]]s of [[Batoidea|rays]] in the order [[Myliobatiformes]], most significantly those belonging to the families [[Dasyatidae]], [[Urotrygonidae]], [[Urolophidae]], and [[Potamotrygonidae]]. [[Stingray]]s generally do not attack aggressively or even actively defend themselves. When threatened, their primary reaction is to swim away. However, when attacked by predators or stepped on, the stinger in their tail is whipped up. This is normally ineffective against [[shark]]s, their main [[predator]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.caribbeanmag.com/search/articles/Cayman_Islands/Stingray_city___diving___snorkeling_grand_cayman.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071008050907/http://www.caribbeanmag.com/search/articles/Cayman_Islands/Stingray_city___diving___snorkeling_grand_cayman.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2007-10-08 | title = About Stingrays | publisher = Caribbean Magazine}}{{rs|date=August 2016}}</ref>
Depending on the size of the stingray, humans are usually stung in the lower limb region.<ref name="eMedicine Health">{{cite web|title=Stingray Injury|url=http://www.emedicinehealth.com/stingray_injury/article_em.htm|publisher=WebMD|accessdate=23 July 2012|author=DuBois, David MD, MS, FAAEM, FACEP|year=2012|quote="People who step on a stingray most frequently are injured on their feet and lower legs."}}</ref> Stings usually occur when swimmers or divers accidentally step on a stingray,<ref name="Slaughter"/> but a human is less likely to be stung by simply brushing against the stinger. Surfers and those who enter waters with large populations of stingrays have learned to slide their feet through the sand rather than taking steps, as the rays detect this and swim away.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aquariumofpacific.org/onlinelearningcenter/species/round_stingray|title=Round Stingray (Round Ray)|last=Pacific|first=Aquarium of the|date=|website=www.aquariumofpacific.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-19}}</ref>
There are reports of stingers breaking off in wounds, but this may be rare.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Clark |first1=Richard F. |last2=Girard |first2=Robyn Heister |last3=Rao |first3=Daniel |last4=Ly |first4=Binh T. |last5=Davis |first5=Daniel P. |title=Stingray Envenomation: A Retrospective Review of Clinical Presentation and Treatment in 119 Cases |journal=The Journal of Emergency Medicine |volume=33 |issue=1 |pages=33–37 |year=2007 |pmid=17630073 |doi=10.1016/j.jemermed.2007.03.043 }}</ref> This would not be fatal to the stingray as it will be regrown at a rate of about {{convert|1.25|to|2|cm|in}} per month (though with significant variations depending on the size of the stingray and the exact species). {{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} Contact with the stinger causes local trauma (from the cut itself), pain, swelling, and muscle cramps from the venom, and possible later infection from bacteria<ref name="Slaughter"/> or fungi.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stingray Injury Case Reports|url=http://www.toxinology.com/fusebox.cfm?staticaction=marine_vertebrates/ns-stingray_injuries.html|work=Clinical Toxicology Resources|publisher=University of Adelaide|accessdate=22 October 2012}}</ref> Immediate injuries to humans include, but are not limited to: [[poisoning]], punctures, severed [[artery|arteries]] and [[vein]]s, and occasionally death.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Taylor |first=G. |title=Toxic fish spine injury: Lessons from 11 years experience. |journal=South Pacific Underwater Medicine Society Journal |volume=30 |issue=1 |year=2000 |issn=0813-1988 |oclc=16986801 |url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/5828 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100416175620/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/5828 |archivedate=2010-04-16 |accessdate=2008-06-15 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healio.com/orthopedics/journals/ORTHO/%7B0002011A-6581-43DB-B0BE-DD20BC56E29A%7D/Stingray-Injury-to-the-Webspace-of-the-Foot |title=Stingray Injury to the Webspace of the Foot | Orthopedics |publisher=Healio.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Yamane |first1=Kunikazu |last2=Asato |first2=Jun |last3=Kawade |first3=Naofumi |last4=Takahashi |first4=Hajime |last5=Kimura |first5=Bon |last6=Arakawa |first6=Yoshichika |title=Two Cases of Fatal Necrotizing Fasciitis Caused by ''Photobacterium damsela'' in Japan |journal=Journal of Clinical Microbiology |volume=42 |issue=3 |pages=1370–72 |year=2004 |pmid=15004123 |pmc=356853 |doi=10.1128/JCM.42.3.1370-1372.2004 }}</ref> Fatal stings are very rare, but can happen,<ref name="Slaughter">{{cite journal |last1=Slaughter |first1=RJ |last2=Beasley |first2=DM |last3=Lambie |first3=BS |last4=Schep |first4=LJ |title=New Zealand's venomous creatures |journal=The New Zealand Medical Journal |volume=122 |issue=1290 |pages=83–97 |year=2009 |pmid=19319171 }}</ref> infamously including [[Steve Irwin]]. In Irwin's case, the stinger penetrated his [[thoracic wall]], causing massive trauma.<ref>{{cite web |author=Crocodile Hunter |url=http://animal.discovery.com/fansites/crochunter/steve-irwin/stingray/stingray.html |title=Discovery Channel Mourns the Death of Steve Irwin |publisher=Animal.discovery.com |date=2012-05-30 |accessdate=2014-03-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130107070254/http://animal.discovery.com/fansites/crochunter/steve-irwin/stingray/stingray.html |archivedate=2013-01-07 |df= }}</ref>
== Whales == {{Main|Killer whale attack}} In [[Western culture]]s, [[killer whale]]s were historically feared as dangerous, savage predators.<ref name="Obee">{{Cite book|isbn = 1-55110-034-7 |last1=Obee |first1=Bruce |first2=Graeme |last2=Ellis |title=Guardians of the Whales: The Quest to Study Whales in the Wild |editor=Elaine Jones |publisher=Whitecap Books |location=North Vancouver, British Columbia |year=1992 |pp=Chapter 1}}</ref> The first written description of a killer whale was given by [[Pliny the Elder]] ''circa'' AD 70, who wrote, "Orcas (the appearance of which no image can express, other than an enormous mass of savage flesh with teeth) are the enemy of [other whales]... they charge and pierce them like warships ramming."<ref>[[Pliny the Elder|Gaius Plinius Secundus]]. [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Pliny_the_Elder/9*.html#v ''Historia Naturalis'' 9.5.12] (Latin), in Bill Thayer's ''[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/home.html LacusCurtius: Into the Roman World]''. (See also an [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.02.0137:book=9:chapter=5 English translation] by [[John Bostock (physician)|John Bostock]] and [[Henry Thomas Riley]], 1855.) Retrieved February 19, 2010.</ref> [[File:Whale of Greifswald from rear.JPG|left|thumb|Male killer whale depicted in St Mary's in [[Greifswald]], Germany, 1545<ref name="Greifswald church">[https://web.archive.org/web/20100120120440/http://www.marien-greifswald.de/Wal.657.0.html Zum Wal in der Marienkirche] (in German). St. Mary's Church, Greifswald. Retrieved February 16, 2010</ref>|alt=Killer whale silhouette, with two projections above shown above the blowhole.]] Of the very few confirmed attacks on humans by wild killer whales, none have been fatal.<ref name="3_News_71245">{{cite news |url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Orca-shares-the-waves-with-local-surfer/tabid/423/articleID/71245/Default.aspx |title=Orca shares the waves with local surfer |date=September 12, 2008 |work=[[3 News]] |accessdate=October 13, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724192551/http://www.3news.co.nz/Orca-shares-the-waves-with-local-surfer/tabid/423/articleID/71245/Default.aspx# |archive-date=24 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In one instance, killer whales tried to tip ice floes on which a dog team and [[Herbert Ponting|photographer]] of the [[Terra Nova Expedition]] were standing.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Cherry-Garrard|first=Apsley|title=The Worst Journey in the World:Antarctic 1910–1913|publisher=Globe Pequot|year=2004|page=92|isbn=1-59228-212-1}}</ref> The sled dogs' barking is speculated to have sounded enough like seal calls to trigger the killer whale's hunting curiosity. In the 1970s, a surfer in California was bitten, and in 2005, a boy in Alaska who was splashing in a region frequented by harbor seals was bumped by a killer whale that apparently misidentified him as prey.<ref name=ketchikan> The Associated Press. [http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2002444869_webwhale18.html "Boy survives bump from killer whale."] ''The Seattle Times'', August 18, 2005. Retrieved January 3, 2010</ref> Unlike wild killer whales, captive killer whales are reported to have made nearly two dozen [[Killer whale attacks on humans|attacks on humans]] since the 1970s, some of which have been fatal.<ref name=abc2006>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=2690153 |title=ABC News: Killer Whale Attacks SeaWorld Trainer |publisher=ABC News |date=November 30, 2006 |accessdate=January 3, 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2010/US/02/24/killer.whale.trainer.death/index.html SeaWorld trainer killed by killer whale]", CNN, February 25, 2010, Retrieved September 9, 2010</ref>
Competition with fishermen also led to killer whales being regarded as pests. In the waters of the [[Pacific Northwest]] and [[Iceland]], the shooting of killer whales was accepted and even encouraged by governments.<ref name="Obee"/> As an indication of the intensity of shooting that occurred until fairly recently, about 25% of the killer whales captured in [[Puget Sound]] for aquarium through 1970 bore bullet scars.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=[[National Marine Fisheries Service]] (NMFS) Northwest Regional Office |author=NMFS |year=2005 |format=PDF |url=http://www.nwr.noaa.gov/Marine-Mammals/Whales-Dolphins-Porpoise/Killer-Whales/Conservation-Planning/upload/SRKW-propConsPlan.pdf |title=Conservation Plan for Southern Resident Killer Whales (''Orcinus orca'') |location=Seattle, U.S.A. |accessdate=January 2, 2009 |ref=harv |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080626121719/http://www.nwr.noaa.gov/Marine-Mammals/Whales-Dolphins-Porpoise/Killer-Whales/Conservation-Planning/upload/SRKW-propConsPlan.pdf |archivedate=June 26, 2008 |deadurl=yes |p=41}}</ref> The U.S. Navy claimed to have deliberately killed hundreds of killer whales in Icelandic waters in 1956 with machine-guns, rockets, and [[Depth charge|depth charges]].<ref>Killer Whales Destroyed: VP-7 Accomplishes Special Task, ''Naval Aviation News'', December 1956, p. 19. Reproduced at [http://www.seaworld.org/infobooks/KillerWhale/deathkw.html Longevity and Causes of Death], SeaWorld/Busch Gardens ANIMALS. Retrieved January 11, 2010</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Naval War Declared Against Killer Whales|journal=The Science News-Letter|volume=69|issue=24|year=1956|page=374|jstor=3936619 |doi=10.2307/3936617}}</ref>
Wild orcas are not considered a real threat to humans, as there is no record of a wild Orca outright attacking or harming a human.<ref name="3 News">{{cite news|title=Orca shares the waves with local surfer|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/nznews/orca-shares-the-waves-with-local-surfer-2008091219|accessdate=May 21, 2015|work=[[3 News]]|date=September 12, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150521193317/http://www.3news.co.nz/nznews/orca-shares-the-waves-with-local-surfer-2008091219#|archive-date=21 May 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media|people=Cowperthwaite, Gabriela (Director)|year=2013|title=[[Blackfish (film)|Blackfish]]|publisher=Magnolia Home Entertainment}}</ref> In captivity, however, there have been several non-fatal and fatal attacks on humans since the 1970s.<ref name="GMA">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.com/GMA/story?id=2690153|title=ABC News: Killer Whale Attacks SeaWorld Trainer|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> Experts are divided as to whether the injuries and deaths were accidental or deliberate attempts to cause harm.<ref name="CSMon">{{cite web|first=Husna |last=Haq |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2010/0225/Sea-World-tragedy-How-common-are-killer-whale-attacks |title=Sea World tragedy: How common are 'killer whale' attacks? |publisher=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date= |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Morris|first=Ethan|title=Why Killer Whales Don't Eat People: Where Science and Legend Meet|url=http://science.kqed.org/quest/2011/07/20/why-killer-whales-don%E2%80%99t-eat-people-where-science-and-legend-meet/|work=QUEST|accessdate=August 6, 2013|date=July 20, 2011}}</ref>
There are a few recorded cases of wild orcas threatening humans. However, there have been no fatalities. <ref name="3 News" /><ref name=Landau2010>{{cite news|last=Landau|first=Elizabeth|title=Biologists: Killer whales 'neurotic' in captivity|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/US/02/25/whales.seaworld.death/index.html|accessdate=August 6, 2013|newspaper=CNN|date=February 26, 2010}}</ref>
== Wild boars == In 2014, a wild boar gored a woman several times while she was walking her dogs. After the initial attack, the woman mistakenly believed the boar had left, and attempted to stand. But the boar attacked again.<ref>{{cite web | title = Vicious Wild Boar Attacks Woman walking with Dogs|publisher=FOX40 |first=Rowena|last=Shaddox|date= 19 November 2014| url = http://fox40.com/2014/11/19/vicious-wild-boar-attacks-woman-walking-with-dogs/ | accessdate = 2015-12-15 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Wild boar attacks Slidell man on Pearl River Wildlife Management Area |publisher=NOLA.com | url = http://www.nola.com/outdoors/index.ssf/2014/02/wild_boar_attacks_slidell_man.html | date=3 February 2014 | accessdate = 2015-12-15 }}</ref>

revision.text:
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Bakri Postpartum Balloon.jpg|300x300px|thumbnail|right|Permission for use granted by Cook Medical Incorporated, Bloomington, Indiana]] -->
The '''Bakri Balloon''' <ref>http://www.cookmedical.com/wh/dataSheet.do?id=4487</ref> is a medical device invented by Younes Bakri, an obstetrician-gynecologist,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bakri|first=Younes|date=|year=1999|title=Balloon device for control of obstetrical bleeding.|url=|journal=Eur J Obstet Gynecol Reprod Biol|volume=86.12: S84.|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.uptodate.com/contents/intrauterine-balloon-tamponade-for-control-of-postpartum-hemorrhage/abstract/3|title=UpToDate|website=www.uptodate.com|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> and manufactured by Cook Medical.<ref>http://www.zoominfo.com/#!search/profile/person?personId=421700382&targetid=profile</ref>
The obstetrical balloon is a 24 [[French catheter scale|French]], 54 cm-long, silicone catheter with a filling capacity of 500 mL. The device is used for the temporary control and reduction of [[postpartum hemorrhage]] (PPH).
According to the [[World Health Organization]], around 100,000 maternal deaths occur every year from PPH and is the leading cause of maternal mortality in the developed world.<ref>Abouzahr C. Antepartum and postpartum haemorrhage. In: Murray CJ, Lopez AD, eds. Health Dimensions of Sex and Reproduction. Boston, Mass: Harvard University Press; 1998:172-4 http://globalhealth.kff.org/GHIR/Conditions/Maternal-Hemorrhage.aspx</ref>
==Use== The Bakri Balloon is a silicone, obstetrical balloon specifically designed to treat [[postpartum hemorrhage]] (PPH). The device is used for the "temporary control or reduction of postpartum hemorrhage when conservative management of uterine bleeding is warranted." <ref>http://www.cookmedical.com/wh/dataSheet.do?id=4487</ref>
==Cases== One study in Finland<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 22913383 | year = 2013 | author1 = Grönvall | first1 = M | title = Use of Bakri balloon tamponade in the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage: A series of 50 cases from a tertiary teaching hospital | journal = Acta Obstetricia et Gynecologica Scandinavica | volume = 92 | issue = 4 | pages = 433–8 | last2 = Tikkanen | first2 = M | last3 = Tallberg | first3 = E | last4 = Paavonen | first4 = J | last5 = Stefanovic | first5 = V | doi = 10.1111/j.1600-0412.2012.01531.x }}</ref> involving 50 patients recorded an overall success rate of 86% when using the Bakri Balloon in managing PPH. A German study involving 20 patients cited an overall success rate of 90% when the balloon is used in combination with [[B-Lynch suture|B-Lynch sutures]].<ref>Diemert A, Ortmeyer G, Hollwitz B, et al. The combination of intrauterine balloon tamponade and the B-Lynch procedure for the treatment of severe postpartum hemorrhage. Am J Obstet Gynecol 2012;206:65.e1-4.</ref>
==Endorsements== Both the [[International Federation of Gynaecology and Obstetrics]] (FIGO) and the [[International Confederation of Midwives]] (ICM) have approved the balloon as one of the primary support tools in treating PPH.<ref>femecog.org.mx/docs/figo_a_b.pdf</ref>
==See also== * [[Postpartum hemorrhage]] * [[Maternal death]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Complications of labour and delivery]] [[Category:Medical equipment]]
