As a consequence, the rate and accuracy of DNA repair mechanisms have an influence over the process of evolutionary change.<ref name="Maresca">{{cite journal | last1 = Maresca | first1 = B | last2 = Schwartz | first2 = JH | year = 2006 | title = Sudden origins: a general mechanism of evolution based on stress protein concentration and rapid environmental change | url = | journal = Anat Rec B New Anat | volume = 289 | issue = 1| pages = 38–46 | pmid = 16437551 | doi = 10.1002/ar.b.20089 }}</ref> DNA damage protection and repair does not influence the rate of adaptation by gene regulation and by recombination and selection of alleles. On the other hand, DNA damage repair and protection does influence the rate of accumulation of irreparable, advantageous, code expanding, inheritable mutations, and slows down the evolutionary mechanism for expansion of the genome of organisms with new functionalities. The tension between evolvability and mutation repair and protection needs further investigation.
==Technology== A technology named clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeat (shortened to [[CRISPR]]-Cas9) was discovered in 2012. The new technology allows anyone with molecular biology training to alter the genes of any species with precision.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/health/crispr-dna-gene-editing-1.3339346 "CRISPR gene-editing tool has scientists thrilled — but nervous" CBC news. Author Kelly Crowe. November 30, 2015.]</ref><br> It is cheaper, more efficient, and more precise than other technologies. With the help of CRISPR–Cas9, parts of a genome can be edited by scientists by removing, adding, or altering parts in a DNA sequence.
==See also== {{Portal|Molecular and Cellular Biology}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Accelerated aging disease]] * [[Aging DNA]] * [[Cell cycle]] * [[DNA damage (naturally occurring)]] * [[DNA damage theory of aging]] * [[DNA replication]] * [[Direct DNA damage]] * [[Gene therapy]] * [[Human mitochondrial genetics]] * [[Indirect DNA damage]] * [[Life extension]] * [[Progeria]] * [[Senescence]] * [[SiDNA]] * The scientific journal ''DNA Repair'' under ''[[Mutation Research (journal)|Mutation Research]]'' {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Library resources box |onlinebooks=yes |by=no |lcheading= DNA repair |label=DNA repair }} {{Spoken Wikipedia|DNA repair.ogg|2005-06-17}} *{{Commonscatinline}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080825230122/http://asajj.roswellpark.org/huberman/DNA_Repair/DNA_Repair.htm Roswell Park Cancer Institute DNA Repair Lectures] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040724083244/http://www.cgal.icnet.uk/DNA_Repair_Genes.html A comprehensive list of Human DNA Repair Genes] *[https://www.webcitation.org/5msbPu0os?url=http://www.biochem.ucl.ac.uk/bsm/xtal/teach/repair/tibs3.html 3D structures of some DNA repair enzymes] *[http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?pid=S0100-84551997000400032&script=sci_arttext&tlng=en Human DNA repair diseases] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060928234605/http://tango01.cit.nih.gov/sig/home.taf?_function=main DNA repair special interest group] *[http://users.rcn.com/jkimball.ma.ultranet/BiologyPages/D/DNArepair.html DNA Repair] *[http://www.benbest.com/lifeext/aging.html#dna DNA Damage and DNA Repair] *[http://www.benbest.com/lifeext/aging.html#progeria Segmental Progeria] *[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/5565866_DNA-damage_repair_the_good_the_bad_and_the_ugly DNA-damage repair; the good, the bad, and the ugly]

page.title: Death and funeral of Otto von Habsburg

revision.comment: Rescuing 9 sources and tagging 3 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
[[File:Lying in repose Otto von Habsburg Capuchin Church Vienna 3921.jpg|thumb|Archduke Otto of Austria<ref name="autogenerated2"/><ref name="kurier-neue-aera"/> and his wife Princess Regina of Saxe-Meiningen lying in repose in the [[Capuchin Church, Vienna|Capuchin Church]], Vienna, draped with the [[Habsburg flag]]. The insignias of the various [[order (honour)|order]]s and decorations accumulated by Habsburg are on display. The Guards of Honour are dressed in [[Military of Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian uniforms]].]] [[File:Kondukt in Wien (102).jpg|thumb|Funeral procession passing the [[Heldenplatz]] (uniforms: Austro-Hungarian [[Hussar]]s and Imperial Riflemen)]] [[File:Kondukt in Wien (38).jpg|thumb|Banner displaying the [[Coat of arms of Austria-Hungary|Imperial & Royal Coat of Arms]], with those of the ''Kronländer'']] On 4 July 2011, [[Otto von Habsburg]], also known as Otto of Austria, former head of the [[House of Habsburg]] and [[wikt:sovereign|Sovereign]] of the [[Order of the Golden Fleece]] (1922–2007) and former [[Crown Prince]] (1916–1918) and, by [[pretender|pretence]], [[Emperor-King]] (from 1922), of [[Austria-Hungary]]—or formally, of [[Emperor of Austria|Austria]], [[King of Hungary|Hungary]] and [[Kingdom of Bohemia|Bohemia]], of [[Kingdom of Dalmatia|Dalmatia]], [[Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia|Croatia, Slavonia]], [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria|Galicia, Lodomeria]] and [[Kingdom of Illyria (1816–1849)|Illyria]], and of [[King of Jerusalem|Jerusalem]] etc. etc.<ref>{{cite web|author=Francois R. Velde |url=http://www.heraldica.org/topics/royalty/royalstyle.htm#austria |title=Royal Styles |publisher=Heraldica.org |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref>—died at 98 years of age.
The following day, a 13-day period of mourning started in several countries formerly part of Austria-Hungary. Otto was entombed in the [[Imperial Crypt]] under the Capuchin Church in Vienna on 16 July and [[Heart-burial|his heart buried]] in [[Pannonhalma Archabbey]] in Hungary on 17 July. Multiple [[requiem]]s were celebrated. Many foreign dignitaries—among them reigning or former monarchs [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden]], [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]], [[King Michael I of Romania]], [[Simeon Saxe-Coburg-Gotha|Tsar Simeon II of Bulgaria]], [[Hans-Adam II, Prince of Liechtenstein]], and Fra' [[Matthew Festing]]—attended the Requiem Mass in Vienna's St. Stephen's Cathedral on 16 July, presided over by Cardinal [[Christoph Schönborn]], which was followed by the entombment in the Imperial Crypt. Commemorations were also held in [[Bavaria]].
This was the most recent burial of a royal Habsburg in the Imperial Crypt—following a centuries-old ceremony—where 145 other members of the House of Habsburg, among them many [[Holy Roman Emperor]]s and Austrian Emperors, have been entombed since 1633.<ref group="f">Otto was the penultimate person to be buried in the Imperial Crypt, because the Crypt is almost full. After Otto's entombment, there is only one remaining place, which is reserved for [[Archduchess Yolande of Austria]], the wife of his brother who was buried there in 2008. Yolande was born in 1923, when Austria-Hungary no longer existed.</ref>
Around 1,000 invited guests and 100,000 members of the public attended the funeral in Vienna, which was broadcast live by [[ORF (broadcaster)|Austrian Television]]. A funeral procession over one kilometer long brought Otto's coffin from St. Stephen's Cathedral to the Imperial Crypt. The ceremonies led to large parts of central Vienna being closed down for public traffic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heute.at/news/oesterreich/wien/Otto-Habsburgs-letzter-Weg-Tausende-nehmen-Abschied;art931,579443 |title=Otto Habsburgs letzter Weg: Tausende nehmen Abschied |publisher=Heute.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-18}}</ref>
The funeral has been described as the "last Emperor's funeral" to take place in Vienna.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salzburg.com/online/nachrichten/newsletter/Wien-erlebte-ein-letztes-Kaiserbegraebnis-.html?article=eGMmOI8VeOOtxHQj6ywvJysdigTfEcXM6VyfxAC&img=&text=&mode= |title=Wien erlebte ein letztes Kaiserbegräbnis |publisher=Salzburg.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref>
==Reaction== [[File:Coronation Hungary 1916.jpeg|thumb|left|[[Otto von Habsburg|Crown Prince Otto]] in [[Budapest]] in 1916, attending his parents' coronation as [[King of Hungary|King and Queen of Hungary]]. Painted by Gyula Éder (inspired by a frame of the coronation film). ]] The eldest son of Charles I, the last Emperor of Austria and King of Hungary, and his wife, Zita of Bourbon-Parma, Otto was born as third in line to the thrones of Austria, Hungary, Croatia and Bohemia. With his father's ascent to the thrones in 1916, he was himself likely to become the Emperor. As his father never abdicated, Otto was considered by himself, his family and Austro-Hungarian legitimists to be the rightful Emperor-King. Forced to live in exile with his family after 1918, Otto was active on the Austrian and European political stage from the 1930s, as an early proponent of European integration and a fierce opponent of Nazism and communism. After the Second World War, he was Vice President (1957–1973) and President (1973–2004) of the [[International Paneuropean Union]], and served as a Member of the [[European Parliament]]. He played a central role in the revolutions of 1989, as a co-initiator of the [[Pan-European Picnic]]. Later he was a strong supporter of the EU membership of central and eastern European countries.
He has been described as "the last Emperor"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/print/die_welt/kultur/article13492692/Der-letzte-Kaiser.html |title=Der letzte Kaiser |language=de |publisher=Welt.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-18}}</ref> or "the last Habsburg".<ref>{{Cite news|author=Michael Fleischhacker|title=Der letzte Habsburger|url=http://diepresse.com/home/politik/innenpolitik/675163/Der-letzte-Habsburger|newspaper=Die Presse|date=2011-07-04|accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>
;Supranational bodies {{flag|EU}} – [[European Commission]] President [[José Manuel Barroso]] said, "with Otto von Habsburg, a great European has left us who gave an important impetus to the European project throughout his rich life. ... [His] commitment to Europe should set a political example for all of us, especially in difficult times." In his statement, Barroso pointed out that Otto had "made a central contribution to the opening of the [[Iron Curtain]] and the peaceful reunification of our continent that had been divided for too long".<ref>{{Cite news|author=Agence France Presse|title=04/07/2011EU, Austria mourn death of Otto Habsburg|url=http://www.expatica.com/de/news/german-news/eu-austria-mourn-death-of-otto-habsburg_160850.html|newspaper=Expatica|accessdate=2011-07-05}}</ref>
:The [[President of the European Parliament]], [[Jerzy Buzek]], stated: "This morning, a European giant passed away [...] In the darkest hours of our continent, Otto von Habsburg has been a rock of truth and humanity. He resisted Nazism with the same determination he opposed the Communist regimes of the [[Eastern bloc]]. He kept the flame of hope for the reunification of Europe alive when many others had given up. I will never forget the moment when the [[Paneuropean Picnic]], which Otto von Habsburg organised on 19 August 1989 at the Austro-Hungarian border, cut the first holes in that Iron Curtain of shame."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/president/view/en/press/press_release/2011/2011-July/press_release-2011-July-2.html |title=President Jerzy Buzek on the death of Otto von Habsburg |publisher=[[European Parliament]] |date=|accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref>
:The [[European Parliament]] held a minute of silence in honour of Otto von Habsburg.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/en/pressroom/content/20110704IPR23247/html/Opening-of-session-Polish-presidency-Moroccan-poll-Belarus-demonstrations |title=Opening of session: Polish presidency, Moroccan poll, Belarus demonstrations |publisher=[[European Parliament]] |date= |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref>
: [[European People's Party]] – President [[Wilfried Martens]] said: "Otto von Habsburg was a great European. He relentlessly defended the European project and European integration".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epp.eu/press.asp?artid=1608&fullview=1 |title=EPP President Wilfried Martens expresses sorrow for the passing away of Otto von Habsburg |publisher=[[European People's Party]] |date= |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref>
: [[European People's Party (European Parliament group)|European People's Party Group]] – Chairman [[Joseph Daul]] stated: "Otto von Habsburg embodied the history of European integration like no-one else. The son of the last Austro-Hungarian emperor fought all his life for democracy, freedom, and an understanding of the peoples of Europe. From the beginnings of the movement for European integration following the end of World War II until the now-famous Paneuropean picnic on the border between Austria and Hungary in 1989, he succeeded in overcoming borders and showing Europeans a way forward to a common future."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eppgroup.eu/press/showpr.asp?prcontroldoctypeid=1&prcontrolid=10490&prcontentid=17713&prcontentlg=en |title=Otto von Habsburg: EPP Group mourns a true European |publisher=[[European People's Party (European Parliament group)|European People's Party Group]] |date= |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref>
[[File:Flag of the Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organisation.svg|22px|UNPO flag]] [[Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization]] – The UNPO secretary-general Marino Busdachin praised Otto as "a champion of multi-culturalism and European integration."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unpo.org/article/12845 |title=General Secretary expresses sadness at passing of Otto von Habsburg |publisher=UNPO |date= |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref>
[[File:International Paneuropean Union flag.svg|22px|Paneuropean Union flag]] [[Paneuropean Union]] – [[Bernd Posselt]], chair of the Paneuropean Union in Germany, said Otto was "the last grand architect of European unity from the pioneer generation."<ref name="traueryahoo" /> Zoltán Wodianer-Nemessuri, chair of the Paneuropean Union in Hungary, stated: "He deserves undying respect in Hungary (for doing) by far the most to ensure that the 1956 [[Hungarian Revolution of 1956|Hungarian Uprising]] should not fade from public memory".<ref name="budapesttimes" />
;States [[File:BentoXVI-15-10052007.jpg|thumb|[[Pope Benedict XVI]] stated that Otto was "a great European" who worked tirelessly for peace, the coexistence of peoples and a just order in Europe]] {{flag|Holy See}} – In a telegram addressed to [[Karl von Habsburg]], Archduke of Austria, [[Pope Benedict XVI]] offered his condolences to the House of Habsburg. Benedict praised Otto von Habsburg as "a great European" who had worked tirelessly for peace, the coexistence of peoples and a just order in Europe. "In the hour of grief over this tragic loss, I associate myself with you and the entire imperial family in prayer for the deceased. In a long and fulfilling life, Archduke Otto was a witness to the eventful history of Europe," the Pope wrote.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Johannes M Schwarz |author2=Erik Diewald |author3=Dorothea Schlee |url=http://www.kath.net/detail.php?id=32263 |title=Benedikt XVI. würdigt Otto von Habsburg |publisher=Kath.Net |date= |accessdate=2011-07-09}}</ref> Cardinal [[Renato Martino]] remembered Otto as one of the twentieth century's "greatest defenders" of the Catholic faith and human dignity, stating that his father, "[[Charles I of Austria|Blessed Karl of Austria]], instilled in him from an early age that the office of a ruler is one of holy service and selfless sacrifice for the good of the peoples entrusted to him. It was a philosophy that would influence him all his life."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/otto-von-habsburg-remembered-as-great-defender-of-christian-values/ |title=Otto von Habsburg remembered as great defender of Christian values |publisher=Catholic News Agency |date= |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref> Cardinal [[Christoph Schönborn]] said that "Otto von Habsburg was without doubt one of the really great Europeans," and that he should be regarded as one of the "architects of the European idea and of European integration" together with [[Robert Schuman]], [[Konrad Adenauer]], and [[Alcide De Gasperi]]. Schörnborn regretted that it had taken so much time for Austria to show "the reasonable gratitude towards the House of Habsburg, which Austria owes so incredibly much" and whose "political and cultural heritage we consume today."<ref name="austriacom" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kathweb.at/site/focus/database/40311.html?SWS=04a92352c9cf628f76e57b8d7708989e |title= Trauer um Otto von Habsburg |publisher=Kathweb.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref>
{{flag|Hungary}} – As the news emerged about Otto's death in Budapest, Hungarian lawmakers immediately held a minute of silence in parliament.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bosnewslife.com/17388-hungary-mourns-last-emperors-son-otto-von-habsburg-dies-at-98 |title=Hungary Mourns Last Emperor’s Son Otto von Habsburg |publisher=Bosnewslife.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref> The [[President of Hungary]], [[Pál Schmitt]], and the [[Prime Minister of Hungary]], [[Viktor Orbán]], both sent their condolences to the Habsburg family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nepszava.hu/articles/article.php?id=446598 |title=Meghalt Habsburg Ottó – részvétet nyilvánított az államfő |publisher=Nepszava.hu |date= |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref><ref name="tvp">{{cite web|url=http://tvp.info/informacje/ludzie/zmarl-syn-ostatniego-cesarza-austrowegier/4824266 |title=Zmarł syn ostatniego cesarza Austro-Węgier |publisher=Tvp.Info |date= |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref> An official government statement said that "his staunch support for the Hungarian cause and for Hungarian people brought him universal recognition and popularity in our country".<ref name="budapesttimes">{{cite web|author=Robert Hodgson|url=http://www.budapesttimes.hu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=19733&Itemid=219 |title=Almost an Emperor|publisher=The Budapest Times |date=2011-07-08 |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref>
{{flag|Austria}} – Austrian president [[Heinz Fischer]] labeled Otto a "loyal citizen of the republic of Austria". Despite the fact that his family was forbidden to enter Austria until Otto formally renounced his claim to the throne, the president noted that his relationship with the republican government "had developed well in the last decades".<ref name="irishtimes" /> Chancellor [[Werner Faymann]] said that "his life reflects the great turning points of the Austrian and European history."<ref name="austriacom">{{cite web|url=http://www.austria.com/europas-politiker-trauern-um-otto-von-habsburg/news-20110705-08504693 |title=Europas Politiker trauern um Otto von Habsburg |publisher=austria.com |date=|accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref>
Former [[Chancellor of Austria]] [[Wolfgang Schüssel]] said that Otto was "a convinced European and paved the way for Austria's road to Europe", and that he "internalized like no other person the all-European idea and articulated it already at a time when there was still a dark shadow over the continent."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung/OTS_20110704_OTS0064/schuessel-trauer-um-dr-otto-habsburg |title=Schüssel: Trauer um Dr. Otto Habsburg |language=de |publisher=ots.at |date=2011-07-04 |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref> [[Othmar Karas]], leader of the European Parliament delegation of the [[Austrian People's Party]], said that "all of Europe is crying."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kurier.at/nachrichten/3919676.php |title=Karas: Ganz Europa weint |publisher=kurier.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref>
{{flag|Czech Republic}} – Foreign Minister [[Karel Schwarzenberg]] praised Otto, stating that Otto had "courageously fought for the peoples imprisoned behind the [[Iron Curtain]]." Schwarzenberg remarked that Otto was the last person who had had a constitutional position "in the old Monarchy", stating that "we should never forget that he was the Crown Prince of Austria, Hungary, and Bohemia." Schwarzenberg also praised Otto's strong anti-Nazi stance, stating that the fact that the annexation of Austria was codenamed "Operation Otto", meant that "the Nazis knew Otto was their main enemy".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung/OTS_20110705_OTS0188/schwarzenberg-otto-von-habsburg-schaetzte-hitler-richtig-ein |title=Schwarzenberg: Otto von Habsburg schätzte Hitler richtig ein |language=de |publisher=ots.at |date=2011-06-30 |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref>
{{flag|Slovenia}} – President [[Danilo Türk]] said: "Otto von Habsburg was one of the strongest advocates of a united Europe, a great man and a promoter of human freedom."<ref name="austriacom" />
{{flag|Latvia}} – Foreign Minister [[Ģirts Valdis Kristovskis]] sent his condolonces to the German Foreign Minister, saying Habsburg's "involvement of spreading European democracy and the European idea will be remembered in Latvia."<ref name="Foreign Minister Kristovskis sent condolences to Dr. Otto von Habsburg family" >{{cite web |url= http://www.mfa.gov.lv/en/news/press-releases/2011/july/06-1/ |title= Foreign Minister Kristovskis sent condolences to Dr. Otto von Habsburg family |work=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Latvia |accessdate=7 July 2011 }}</ref>
{{flag|Macedonia}} – President [[Gjorge Ivanov]] sent his letter of condolences to the Habsburg family, stating that Otto von Habsburg was a "friend of the Republic of Macedonia" and that "he never forgot about Macedonia."<ref name="Letter of Condolonces following the death of Dr. Otto von Habsburg">{{cite web |url = http://www.president.gov.mk/en/public-relations/press-release/541-2011-07-04-13-47-37.html |title = Letter of Condolonces following the death of Dr. Otto von Habsburg |work = Office of the President of Macedonia |accessdate = 7 July 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110808040357/http://www.president.gov.mk/en/public-relations/press-release/541-2011-07-04-13-47-37.html# |archive-date = 8 August 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
{{flag|Kosovo}} – President [[Atifete Jahjaga]] sent her condolences to the Habsburg court, stating that "with deep sorrow I heard the news of the death of his Majesty Archduke Otto von Habsburg. Today, Europe has lost a prominent politician, the great proponent of peace and a contributor to its union, while Kosovo has lost an irreplaceable friend who will be considered and remembered forever. On this painful occasion, on behalf of the Republic of Kosovo and its citizens, and on my personal behalf, I express my most heartfelt condolences and my deepest sympathy to the Court of Habsburg."<ref name="Letter of Condolonces to the Habsburg Court following Otto von Habsburg death" >{{cite web |url= http://www.president-ksgov.net/?page=2,6,1874 |title= Letter of Condolonces to the Habsburg court following Otto von Habsburg death |work=Office of the President of Kosovo |accessdate=7 July 2011 }}</ref>
{{flag|Croatia}} – Foreign Minister [[Gordan Jandroković]] sent his condolences to the Habsburg family, and described Otto as "a great political role model, a great European and a relentless promoter of human rights." He said that the Croatian people always had a great friend in Otto and that he will be especially remembered for his involvement and contribution to the international recognition of the Republic of Croatia, as well as for his support to Croatia's membership in the European Union.<ref name="Croatia">{{cite web |url = http://www.mvpei.hr/custompages/static/hrv/templates/_frt_Priopcenja_en.asp?id=6928 |title = Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs and European Integration Gordan Jandroković sent a letter of condolences to the family of the deceased Dr Otto von Habsburg-Lothringen |work = Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Croatia |accessdate = 8 July 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110709040503/http://www.mvpei.hr/custompages/static/hrv/templates/_frt_Priopcenja_en.asp?id=6928# |archive-date = 9 July 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
;Domestic
{{flag|Germany}} – Member of Parliament and President of the [[Federation of Expellees]] [[Erika Steinbach]] praised Otto as "a strong supporter of the refugees and a compassionate intermediary between the peoples of Europe".<ref name="traueryahoo">{{cite web|url=http://de.nachrichten.yahoo.com/trauer-um-otto-von-habsburg-171236234.html |title=Trauer um Otto von Habsburg |publisher=yahoo.com |date=2011-04-20 |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref> :{{flag|Bavaria}} – The ruling [[Christian Social Union of Bavaria]], the party which Otto represented as a [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]], issued a statement, stating, "the CSU mourns the death of His Imperial and Royal Highness Dr. Otto von Habsburg."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.csu.de/partei/unsere_politik/174111133.htm |title=Ein aufrechter Demokrat und überzeugter Europäer |publisher=csu.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927012848/http://www.csu.de/partei/unsere_politik/174111133.htm# |archive-date=27 September 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Prime Minister [[Horst Seehofer]] lauded Otto as "an advocate for Europe, a defender of freedom, and of the faith and our values." He also mentioned Otto's role in bringing down the [[Iron Curtain]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nachrichten.t-online.de/seehofer-wuerdigt-otto-von-habsburg-als-anwalt-europas-/id_47687270/index?news |title=Seehofer würdigt Otto von Habsburg als "Anwalt Europas" |publisher=Nachrichten.t-online.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323100128/http://nachrichten.t-online.de/seehofer-wuerdigt-otto-von-habsburg-als-anwalt-europas-/id_47687270/index?news# |archive-date=23 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Funeral== His funeral took place on 16 July 2011 in [[Vienna]] and on 17 July in [[Pannonhalma Archabbey]], Hungary.<ref name="irishtimes">{{Cite news|title=Death of former 'kaiser in exile' and last heir to Austro-Hungarian throne|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/0705/1224300090924.html|date=4 July 2011|newspaper=The Irish Times|accessdate=2011-07-05|first=Derek|last=Scally}}</ref> A 13-day period of mourning started in several countries formerly part of Austria-Hungary on 5 July 2011, when the body of Archduke Otto<ref name="kurier-neue-aera">{{cite web|url=http://kurier.at/nachrichten/3921018.php |title=Karl Habsburg: "Neue Ära beginnt" |publisher=kurier.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-09}}</ref> was laid in repose in the Church of St. Ulrich near his home in [[Pöcking]], [[Bavaria]].<ref name="monstersandcritics2">{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1649322.php/Thirteen-days-of-commemoration-for-Otto-von-Habsburg-begins |title=Thirteen days of commemoration for Otto von Habsburg begins |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111103002040/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1649322.php/Thirteen-days-of-commemoration-for-Otto-von-Habsburg-begins |archivedate=3 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The body was transferred by train to the Catholic [[Mariazell Basilica|pilgrimage basilica]] in [[Mariazell]] on 12 July,<ref name="kleinezeitung1">{{cite web|author=Ulf Tomaschek |url=http://www.kleinezeitung.at/nachrichten/chronik/2779877/ein-abschied-fuer-volk-familie.story |title=Ein Abschied für das Volk und die Familie |publisher=Kleinezeitung.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref> before being transferred by train to Vienna.<ref name="monstersandcritics2" /> [[Requiem Mass]]es were celebrated in three countries, in Munich, Pöcking, Mariazell, Vienna, and Budapest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wien.orf.at/stories/524598/ |title=Otto Habsburg: Beisetzung am 16. Juli in Wien |publisher=Wien.orf.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref> In accordance with the Habsburg tradition, his body and heart were buried separately.<ref name="kleinezeitung2">{{cite web|author=Michael Jungwirth |url=http://www.kleinezeitung.at/nachrichten/politik/2778838/otto-habsburg-trauerzug-halb-europa.story |title=Ein Trauerzug durch halb Europa |publisher=Kleinezeitung.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref><ref name="mariazell">{{cite web |url=http://www.mariazell.at/index.php/Latest/Begrabnisfeierlichkeiten1-laufen-auf-Hochturen056.html |title=Requiem für Otto von Habsburg |publisher=Mariazell.at |date=2007-12-16 |accessdate=2011-07-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110709184758/http://www.mariazell.at/index.php/Latest/Begrabnisfeierlichkeiten1-laufen-auf-Hochturen056.html# |archive-date=9 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Otto was entombed in the Imperial Crypt (''Kapuzinergruft'') together with his mother, wife and other family members.<ref name="derstandard1">{{cite news|url=http://derstandard.at/1308680318628/Requiem-im-Stephansdom-Beisetzung-in-Wiener-Kapuzinergruft |title=Beisetzung in Wiener Kapuzinergruft |publisher=Derstandard.at |date=2011-04-07 |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref> His [[Heart-burial|heart was buried]] in [[Pannonhalma Archabbey]] in Hungary.<ref name="irishtimes"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://derstandard.at/1308680490680/Otto-Habsburgs-letzte-Reise-durch-Europa |title=Otto Habsburgs letzte Reise durch Europa |publisher=Derstandard.at |date=2011-06-07 |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kurier.at/nachrichten/3919635.php |title=Habsburgs Leichnam in Pöcking aufgebahrt |publisher=kurier.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref> Crown Prince Otto was educated by monks from [[Pannonhalma Benedictine College]].<ref name="mariazell" /> He was exiled from Austria and Hungary in 1918. [[File:Kondukt in Wien (215).jpg|thumb|Cardinal [[Christoph Schönborn]] and the papal nuncio, Archbishop Peter Zurbriggen, during the funeral procession]] [[File:Kondukt in Wien (67).jpg|thumb|Funeral procession at Heldenplatz with big screen in the background]] [[File:Kondukt in Wien (269).jpg|thumb|The King and Queen of Sweden during the procession]] The funeral has been described as a major event in Vienna's history; Cardinal Schönborn described it as "a historic moment for Austria", stating that it will be good for the country to "think of this great Habsburger in prayer and gratitude".<ref name="derstandard1" /> Otto's mother, former [[Zita of Bourbon-Parma|Empress-Queen Zita]]'s funeral in 1989, was attended by 40,000 people.<ref name="monstersandcritics2" />
Otto was buried with military honours. The funeral in Vienna was broadcast live by [[ORF (broadcaster)|Austrian Television]] and the requiem was also screened on big screens at [[Stephansplatz, Vienna|Stephansplatz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kurier.at/nachrichten/3922972.php |title= Begräbnismarathon am Samstag |date= |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref><ref name="kathweb1">{{cite web|url=http://www.kathweb.at/site/nachrichten/database/40401.html |title= Habsburg-Trauerfeiern in Wien: Vorbereitungen auf Hochtouren |date= |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref><ref name="volat1">{{cite web|url=http://www.vol.at/habsburg-vorbereitung-fuer-trauerfeiern-laeuft-auf-hochtouren/news-20110708-01112494 |title=Habsburg: Vorbereitung für Trauerfeiern läuft auf Hochtouren |publisher=Vol.at |date=2008-01-25 |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref> The funeral procession through [[Innere Stadt]] was over one kilometer long.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.oe24.at/oesterreich/chronik/habsburg/Video-Walls-in-Wiener-City-Habsburg-1-2-Kilometer-Trauerzug/33576295 |title= Habsburg: 1,2 Kilometer Trauerzug |publisher=Oe24.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-09}}</ref> Following the procession, Otto was entombed in the Imperial Crypt. A blessing from Pope Benedict XVI was read during the requiem.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wien.orf.at/stories/525868/ |title=Habsburg: Begräbnis 'seit 12 Jahren geplant' |publisher=Wien.orf.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
Otto was the penultimate person to be entombed in the Imperial Crypt, where 145 other members of his family have been entombed since 1633, because the Crypt is almost full.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.salzburg.com/online/homepage/aktuell/Platzmangel-in-der-Kaisergruft.html?article=eGMmOI8VeOOtxHQj6ywvQnOJO4TfuQfWXOOC0oU&img=&text=&mode= |title=Platzmangel in der Kaisergruft |publisher=salzburg.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In [[Bavaria]], the ruling [[Christian Social Union of Bavaria]] organised the largest commemorations in the state since the death of its former Prime Minister [[Franz Josef Strauss]]; the commemorations included the celebration of two requiems and a reception at the [[Munich Residenz]].
Otto's coffin was draped with the [[Habsburg flag|Habsburg imperial flag]] in black-yellow and featuring the imperial-royal coats of arms of Austria and Hungary in addition to the Habsburg family coat of arms.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/regionales/muenchen/article13470091/Kaisersohn-Otto-von-Habsburg-aufgebahrt.html |title= Kaisersohn Otto von Habsburg aufgebahrt |language=de |publisher=Welt.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/print/welt_kompakt/vermischtes/article13470494/Abschied-am-Sarg.html |title=Abschied am Sarg |language=de |publisher=Welt.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref>
Otto von Habsburg wrote that the funeral of [[Franz Joseph I of Austria]] in 1916 had been the most profound experience of his childhood; the 4-year old had attended the funeral dressed completely in white among all the adults dressed in black.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kurier.at/nachrichten/3920080.php |title=Ottos Erinnerung an den Trauerzug für Franz Joseph I. |publisher=kurier.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref>
Otto's funeral was organised by his sons, [[Karl von Habsburg]], head of the House of Habsburg, and [[Georg von Habsburg]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://diepresse.com/home/politik/innenpolitik/675147/Im-Kreise-seiner-Familie |title=Im Kreise seiner Familie|publisher=Diepresse.com |date=2010-03-31 |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref> Karl von Habsburg revealed that the planning for the funeral had started 12 years earlier, and that Otto had not involved himself in it, except for expressing the wish for a ceremony in Hungary in line with the family tradition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung/OTS_20110710_OTS0030/habsburg-tod-sohn-informiert-in-orf-radio-ueber-weitere-details |title=Habsburg-Tod: Sohn informiert in ORF-Radio über weitere Details |language=de |publisher=ots.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
The Imperial Crypt of the Habsburg family is each year visited by around 200,000 people. The Crypt was constructed in accordance with the will of [[Anna of Tyrol|Empress Anna]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kleinezeitung.at/magazin/reise/2779439/kaisergruft-wiener-touristenattraktion.story |title=Kaisergruft als Wiener Touristenattraktion |publisher=Kleinezeitung.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref>
The sarcophagus of Otto's wife [[Princess Regina of Saxe-Meiningen|Regina]], who was interred in her family crypt in the castle of Veste Heldburg in Germany in 2010, was transferred to Mariazell and then to the Imperial Crypt in Vienna at the same time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mainpost.de/regional/hassberge/Regina-von-Habsburg-tritt-ihre-letzte-Reise-an;art1726,6225530 |title=Regina von Habsburg tritt ihre letzte Reise an |publisher=Mainpost.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref> However, Regina's heart will remain in her family crypt in Veste Heldburg.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insuedthueringen.de/lokal/hildburghausen/hildburghausen/art83436,1690570 |title='Puttis' Herz bleibt in Heldburg |publisher=Insuedthueringen.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
The security measures were reportedly massive.<ref name="oe24-1" /> Large parts of central Vienna were closed down for public traffic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.austria.com/habsburg-begraebnis-fuehrt-zu-behinderungen/news-20110714-02334482 |title=Habsburg: Begräbnis führt zu Behinderungen |publisher=austria.com |date=2008-01-25 |accessdate=2011-07-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wienweb.at/content.aspx?menu=1&cid=178993 |title=Habsburg-Begräbnis: Station Stephansplatz wird gesperrt |publisher=www.wienweb.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-12 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The small [[The Greens – The Green Alternative|Austrian Green Party]] criticized the government for the extensive state involvement in the funeral, which made it indistinguishable from a [[state funeral]] in their opinion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://diepresse.com/home/politik/677253/Gruene-kritisieren-Kosten-fuer-HabsburgBegraebnis?_vl_backlink=/home/politik/674867/index.do&direct=674867 |title=Grüne kritisieren Kosten für Habsburg-Begräbnis |publisher=Diepresse.com |date=2010-03-31 |accessdate=2011-07-13}}</ref>
The funeral was said to have nourished Austria's important tourist industry; according to a study, the imperial Habsburg heritage is the main reason tourists visit the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.n-tv.de/reise/Touristen-kommen-wegen-K-u-K-Flair-article3811951.html |title= Österreich und sein imperiales Erbe: Touristen kommen wegen K.u.K.-Flair |publisher=n-tv.de |date=2010-03-31 |accessdate=2011-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://derstandard.at/1310511370304/Habsburger-Ein-Geschenk-Gottes-an-die-Tourismusindustrie |title= Ein Geschenk Gottes an die Tourismusindustrie |publisher= derstandard.at |date=2010-03-31 |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>
The Malteser Hospitaldienst Austria (MHDA), an organisation which is subordinated to the [[Order of Malta]], was responsible for providing medical assistance.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.erzdioezese-wien.at/content/news/articles/2011/07/14/a26294/ |title=Starke Malteserpräsenz bei den Trauerfeiern |publisher=Erzdioezese-wien.at |date=2011-07-14 |accessdate=2011-07-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326203909/http://www.erzdioezese-wien.at/content/news/articles/2011/07/14/a26294/# |archive-date=26 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Requiems and ceremonies=== Six requiems in four countries were celebrated.
[[File:Otto of Austria funeral Poecking4-cropped1.jpg|thumb|Procession in Pöcking on 9 July with Otto's coffin draped with the Habsburg imperial flag. The pallbearers are dressed in Austro-Hungarian uniforms.]] [[File:Lying in repose Otto von Habsburg Capuchin Church Vienna 3947.jpg|thumb|People queueing outside the Capuchin Church to pay their last respects during the lying in repose on 15 July]] {{flagicon|Bavaria}} [[Pöcking]], [[Bavaria]] – The requiem masses were initiated with a mass for ''His Imperial and Royal Highness Archduke Otto of Austria, Prince Royal of Hungary'', celebrated on 9 July by Bishop Konrad Zdarsa of Augsburg in the St. Pius church in Pöcking, near Otto's home.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/regionales/muenchen/article13479288/Hunderte-ehren-den-Kaisersohn.html |title=Otto von Habsburg: Hunderte ehren den Kaisersohn |language=de |publisher=Welt.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref><ref name="sueddeutsche1" />
{{flagicon|Bavaria}} [[Munich]], [[Bavaria]] – The second requiem mass was celebrated in the [[Theatine Church, Munich|Theatine Church]] in Munich on 11 July at 10:00 by Cardinal [[Reinhard Marx]] and co-celebrated by his predecessor, Cardinal [[Friedrich Wetter]]<ref name="autogenerated2"/><ref name="sueddeutsche1">{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/u5P38Z/89460/Requiem-fuer-Otto-von-Habsbur.html |title=Requiem für Otto von Habsburg |publisher=sueddeutsche.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=sueddeutsche.de GmbH, Munich, Germany |url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/L5V38s/99177/Auch-Papst-Benedikt-kondoliert-der-kaiserlichen-FamilieThronfolger-ohne-Thro.html |title=Auch Papst Benedikt kondoliert der kaiserlichen Familie |publisher=sueddeutsche.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-12}}</ref> The requiem was screened on big screens at [[Odeonsplatz]] and broadcast by [[Bayerischer Rundfunk|Bavarian Television]]. Munich's senior rabbi, Steven Langnas, recited a Jewish funeral prayer. In closing, ''[[Gott erhalte Franz den Kaiser|God Save Our Emperor]]'', the old Austrian imperial anthem, was sung.<ref>Gott erhalte Franz den Kaiser</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salzburg.com/online/nachrichten/newsletter/Zum-Abschied-die-Kaiserhymne.html?article=eGMmOI8V5CIeeLYRkKSGyUAP0MtJGdOg9Z4l3Om&img=&text=&mode= |title=Zum Abschied die Kaiserhymne |publisher=Salzburg.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref> Following the requiem [[Prime Minister of Bavaria]] [[Horst Seehofer]] hosted a reception for around 700 invited guests in the ''Kaisersaal'' of the [[Munich Residenz]]. Among those attending the requiem and reception were former Austrian Chancellor [[Wolfgang Schüssel]], members of the [[House of Wittelsbach]], of the [[Order of Malta]] and the [[Order of the Golden Fleece]], and other European royals and leading politicians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europeonline-magazine.eu/pontifikalrequiem-fuer-otto-von-habsburg-in-muenchen_141167.html |title=Pontifikalrequiem für Otto von Habsburg in München|publisher=Europeonline-magazine.eu |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merkur-online.de/lokales/starnberg/otto-habsburg-groesste-trauerfeier-seit-strauss-1309597.html |title=Otto von Habsburg: Die größte Trauerfeier seit Franz Josef Strauß |language=de |publisher=Merkur-online.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://relevant.at/society/kings-queens/162557/habsburg-muenchner-requiem-tv-leinwand.story |title=Habsburg - Münchner Requiem im TV und auf Leinwand |publisher=Relevant.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.focus.de/panorama/welt/leute-kardinal-marx-wuerdigt-einsatz-otto-von-habsburgs_aid_644703.html |title= Kardinal Marx würdigt Einsatz Otto von Habsburgs |publisher=Focus.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/muenchen/starnberg/poecking-abschied-vom-kaisersohn-1.1118713 |title= Abschied vom Kaisersohn |publisher=sueddeutsche.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref> [[File:Requiem Otto von Habsburg Mariazell (56).jpg|thumb|left|Members of the House of Habsburg arriving in Mariazell for the requiem]] {{flagicon|Austria}} [[Mariazell]], [[Austria]] – The third requiem was celebrated by Bishop Egon Kapellari in the pilgrimage town of [[Mariazell]] on 13 July 2011 at 14:00, with around 1,000 members of the high nobility and leading politicians present.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wienerzeitung.at/nachrichten/panorama/chronik/334776_Der-letzte-Weg-des-Kaisersohnes.html |title=Tausend bei Habsburg-Requiem |publisher=Wienerzeitung.at |date=2011-05-18 |accessdate=2011-07-13}}</ref> Mariazell has for centuries been the most important pilgrimage town for the House of Habsburg, and large parts of the former Austria-Hungary.<ref name="kleinezeitung3">{{cite web|url=http://www.kleinezeitung.at/steiermark/bruckandermur/mariazell/2780208/habsburger-mariazell.story |title= Die Habsburger und Mariazell |publisher=kleinezeitung.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kleinezeitung.at/steiermark/bruckandermur/mariazell/2783679/vielfaeltige-symbolik-bei-trauerfeier-otto-habsburg-mariazell.story |title=Vielfältige Symbolik bei Trauerfeier von Otto Habsburg in Mariazell |publisher=Kleinezeitung.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Austria}} [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] – The main funeral ceremony took place in Vienna. The requiem was celebrated in [[St. Stephen's Cathedral, Vienna|St. Stephen's Cathedral]] on 16 July 2011 from 15:00, and was presided over by Cardinal [[Christoph Schönborn]], assisted by seven bishops from the various nations of Austria-Hungary.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jahn |first=George |url=http://www.ajc.com/news/nation-world/oldest-son-of-austrias-1019916.html |title=Oldest son of Austria's last emperor buried |publisher=ajc.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-18}}</ref> A message from Pope Benedict XVI, addressed to His Imperial Highness, Archduke Karl of Austria, was read by the papal [[nuncio]], Archbishop Peter Zurbriggen. The requiem was followed by a funeral procession through [[Innere Stadt]] and the entombment (following [[#Entombment ceremony|the traditional ceremony]]) of Otto and his wife, Regina, in the Imperial Crypt. Cardinal Schönborn said that the collection which was taken was given to the victims of the [[2011 Horn of Africa drought]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung/OTS_20110715_OTS0074/habsburg-requiem-kollekte-fuer-duerreopfer-in-afrika |title= Habsburg-Requiem: Kollekte für Dürreopfer in Afrika |publisher=ots.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref>
While Otto and Regina were lying in repose in the [[Capuchin Church, Vienna|Capuchin Church]], Christian, Jewish and Muslim prayers—reflecting the multicultural and multi-religious heritage of Austria-Hungary—were read on Thursday 14 July, by Bishop Stephan Turnovszky, Rabbi Steven Langnas, and Grand Mufti [[Mustafa Cerić]], respectively. On Friday 15 July, the Jewish community organised a ceremony in the [[Stadttempel]], Vienna's main synagogue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.austria.com/habsburg-interreligioese-totengebete-in-kapuzinerkirche/news-20110712-04531382 |title=Habsburg: Interreligiöse Totengebete in Kapuzinerkirche |publisher=austria.com |date=2008-01-25 |accessdate=2011-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/christian-jewish-and-muslim-clerics-pray-for-late-son-of-last-austrian-emperor-and-wife/2011/07/14/gIQAomcdEI_story.html |title= Christian, Jewish and Muslim clerics pray for late son of last Austrian emperor and wife |publisher=The Washington Post |date=|accessdate=2011-07-14 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vienna.at/die-juedische-gemeinde-betet-fuer-otto-von-habsburg/news-20110715-09205265 |title= Die jüdische Gemeinde betet für Otto von Habsburg |publisher=vienna.at |date=|accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>
During the lying in repose on 15 July, guards in traditional uniform stood in honour on either side of the two coffins, draped in the imperial yellow-black flag. Thousands of people paid their respect, and visitors were able to write into books of condolence. In front of the coffins, a number of [[Order (honour)|orders]], honours and decorations that Otto received throughout his life were laid out on velvet cushions. They include the [[Order of the Golden Fleece]], Grand Cross of the [[Order of Saint Stephen of Hungary]], Grand Cross of the [[Order of Leopold (Austria)|Order of Leopold]], [[Order of the Most Holy Annunciation]], [[Order of Saint Januarius]], [[Order of Saint Hubert]], Grand Cross of the [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]], Grand Cross of the [[Legion of Honour]], Grand Cross of the [[Order of Merit]], Sovereign Military Order of Malta Grand Cross Bailiff of Grace and Devotion, Grand Cross of the [[Order of Charles III]], Grand Cross of the [[Order of St. Gregory the Great]], and many others (for a list see [http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Lying_in_repose_Otto_von_Habsburg_Capuchin_Church_Vienna_3933.jpg here]).
{{flagicon|Croatia}} [[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]] – On 16 July, a requiem was also celebrated in [[Croatia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.suedkurier.de/news/panorama/panorama/Gedenken-auch-in-Suedosteuropa;art410967,5004664 |title=Gedenken auch in Südosteuropa |publisher=Suedkurier.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref>
{{flagicon|Hungary}} [[Budapest]] and [[Pannonhalma]], [[Hungary]] – The last requiem mass took place on Sunday, 17 July 2011 at 15:00, and was celebrated by Cardinal [[László Paskai]] and co-celebrated by Pannonhalma Archabbot [[Asztrik Várszegi]] and a number of Hungarian bishops in [[St. Stephen's Basilica]] in [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]].<ref name="kathweb-hungary">{{cite web|url=http://www.kathweb.at/site/nachrichten/database/40391.html |title= Ökumene-Feier zur Herzbestattung Habsburgs |publisher=Kathweb.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-12}}</ref> Finally Otto's heart was interred in [[Pannonhalma Archabbey]] with only the closest family present.<ref name="sueddeutsche1" />
=== Entombment ceremony === [[File:Kaisergruft Otto von Habsburg-Lothringen.JPG|thumb|Tomb at Imperial Crypt]] [[File:Wien kapuzinergruft002.jpg|thumb|left|An ornament of the sarcophagus of Otto's ancestor, [[Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor]], in the [[Imperial Crypt]]: a death's head with the [[Imperial Crown of the Holy Roman Empire|Imperial Crown]]]] A traditional ceremony during the funeral is when the procession of mourners arrives at the gates of the Capuchin Church, under which the Imperial Crypt lies, and the Herald knocks on the door. A [[Order of Friars Minor Capuchin|Capuchin]] then asks "who demands entry?" The Herald responds with the name and title of the deceased. The Capuchin then responds "we don't know him/her." The same procedure is repeated once. Only on the third attempt, when the Herald responds with "a sinful, mortal human being", are the gates opened and the dead Habsburg admitted into the Crypt. In 1989, Otto's mother, [[Zita of Bourbon-Parma|Zita]], was first introduced with all her titles, and the second time introduced as "Zita, Her Majesty the Empress and Queen".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://derstandard.at/1308680797958/Viel-Pomp-auf-dem-Weg-in-die-Kapuzinergruft |title=Viel Pomp auf dem Weg in die Kapuzinergruft |publisher=[[Der Standard]] |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
Ulrich-Walter Lipp, a friend of the family, was chosen to be the Herald in 2011. Otto was first introduced as "Otto of Austria; former Crown Prince of Austria-Hungary; Prince Royal of [[Kingdom of Hungary|Hungary]] and [[Kingdom of Bohemia|Bohemia]], of [[Kingdom of Dalmatia|Dalmatia]], [[Kingdom of Croatia and Slavonia|Croatia, Slavonia]], [[Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria|Galicia, Lodomeria]], and [[Kingdom of Illyria (1816–1849)|Illyria]]; Grand Duke of [[Grand Duchy of Tuscany|Tuscany]] and [[Grand Duchy of Cracow|Cracow]]; Duke of [[Lorraine (duchy)|Lorraine]], of [[Duchy of Salzburg|Salzburg]], [[Duchy of Styria|Styria]], [[Duchy of Carinthia|Carinthia]], [[Duchy of Carniola|Carniola]] and [[Duchy of Bukovina|Bukowina]]; Grand Prince of [[Grand Principality of Transylvania|Transylvania]], Margrave of [[Margraviate of Moravia|Moravia]]; [[Duchy of Upper and Lower Silesia|Duke of Silesia]], [[Duchy of Modena|Modena]], [[Duchy of Parma|Parma, Piacenza]], [[Duchy of Guastalla|Guastalla]], [[Duchy of Auschwitz|Auschwitz]] and [[Duchy of Zator|Zator]], [[Duchy of Teschen|Teschen]], [[Duchy of Friuli|Friuli]], [[Dubrovnik]] and [[Zadar]]; Princely Count of [[House of Habsburg#History#Counts of Habsburg|Habsburg]] and [[County of Tyrol|Tyrol]], of [[County of Kyburg|Kyburg]], [[Gorizia and Gradisca]]; Prince of [[Trento|Trent]] and [[Brixen]]; Margrave of [[Upper Lusatia|Upper]] and [[March of Lusatia|Lower Lusatia]] and [[March of Istria|Istria]]; Count of [[Hohenems]], [[Feldkirch, Vorarlberg|Feldkirch]], [[County of Bregenz|Bregenz]], [[Waldburg-Sonnenburg|Sonnenburg]] etc.; Lord of [[Trieste]], [[Kotor]] and the [[Windic March]], Grand Voivod of the [[Voivodeship of Serbia and Banat of Temeschwar|Voivodeship of Serbia]] etc. etc."<ref name="kathweb-introduction"/><ref name="diepresse-introduction"/> The traditional [[Emperor of Austria#Titles of the Emperor|Habsburg claims to Jerusalem and Austria]] were omitted.
The second time he was introduced as "Dr. Otto von Habsburg" and a number of his civic achievements, notably as President of the [[Paneuropean Union]] and [[Member of the European Parliament]], mentioned. "Otto Habsburg-Lothringen", the name Austrian authorities use when referring to him, was not used.<ref name="kathweb-introduction"/><ref name="diepresse-introduction"/>
The third time he was introduced as "Otto, a mortal, sinful human being!"<ref name="kathweb-introduction">{{cite web|url=http://www.kathweb.at/site/nachrichten/database/40470.html |title= Habsburg-Begräbnis mit Anklopf-Zeremonie an Wiener Kapuzinergruft |publisher=Kathweb.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-12}}</ref><ref name="diepresse-introduction">{{cite web|url=http://diepresse.com/home/politik/zeitgeschichte/677366/Klopfzeremonie_Wer-begehrt-Einlass?direct=674867&_vl_backlink=/home/politik/index.do&selChannel=624 |title=Klopfzeremonie: 'Wer begehrt Einlass?' |publisher=Diepresse.com |date=2010-03-31 |accessdate=2011-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Benjamin Greschner |url=http://kathnews.de/cms/cms/front_content.php?idart=1065 |title= Vor Gott zählen nur Glaube und Gute Werke: Wortlaut und Sinn der 'Anklopf-Zeremonie' an der Wiener Kapuzinerkirche |publisher=Kathnews.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-13}}</ref>
The Capuchin opening the gates, finally exclaiming "So he may come in", was Father Gottfried Undesser, the custodian of the Imperial Crypt, born in 1933 and a Capuchin since 1951. It was also Father Gottfried who opened the gates for Empress-Queen Zita in 1989.<ref>[http://www.gatterhoelzl.at/joomla/files/Pfarrblatt/Archiv/Sommer-2006.pdf Gatterhölzner Pfarrnachrichten, No. 101/2006]</ref> The Capuchins have been in charge of building and maintaining the Imperial Crypt since 1622.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heute.at/news/oesterreich/wien/Pater-Gottfried-oeffnet-Otto-Habsburg-die-Pforte-zur-Kapuzinergruft;art931,576840 |title= Pater Gottfried öffnet Otto Habsburg die Pforte zur Kapuzinergruft |publisher=heute.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://diepresse.com/home/politik/zeitgeschichte/678145/Der-Waechter-der-Kaisergruft |title= Der Wächter der Kaisergruft |publisher=diepresse.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nachrichten.at/nachrichten/chronik/art58,669975 |title= ChronikGottfried Undesser: Der Hüter der Kapuzinergruft |publisher=nachrichten.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref>
===Heart burial=== [[File:Pannonhalma - Bencés apátság.jpg|thumb|His heart was laid to rest in [[Pannonhalma Archabbey]] in Hungary]] On Sunday 17 July 2011, Otto's heart was buried in the Benedictine [[Pannonhalma Archabbey]], following a ceremony with [[vespers]] in Latin, and an [[ecumenical]] prayer. Archabbot Asztrik Várszegi, Reformed Bishop [[Gusztáv Bölcskei]], Lutheran Bishop Tamás Fabinyi, and Chief Rabbi Zsolt Markovics participated, together with around hundred members of the House of Habsburg and Deputy Prime Minister [[Zsolt Semjén]] with his wife representing the Hungarian government.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.politics.hu/20110718/heart-of-otto-von-habsburg-interred-in-pannonhalma/ |title=Heart of Otto von Habsburg interred in Pannonhalma |publisher=Politics.hu |date= |accessdate=2011-07-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816220238/http://www.politics.hu/20110718/heart-of-otto-von-habsburg-interred-in-pannonhalma/# |archive-date=16 August 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A silver urn containing his heart was surrounded by a wreath of flowers and leaves in the colours of the [[Hungarian flag]]—red, white and green. His sons Karl (Károly in Hungary) and Georg (György) finally carried the urn to the crypt, where it was buried under a marble slab.<ref name="bbc14181800">{{cite news|last=Bell |first=Bethany |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-14181800 |title=Habsburg funeral sparks nostalgia and admiration |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= 18 July 2011|accessdate=2011-07-18}}</ref>
Father Albin, one of the monastery's monks, said that "Hungary never expelled him personally, and he wanted to be buried in a country which still loves him."<ref name="bbc14181800"/>
With the burial of his heart, 12 days of commemoration and funeral ceremonies in several countries were concluded.
His heart urn lists his name and titles as: :S.K.K.H. [His Imperial and Royal Highness] :Otto :Erzherzog von Österreich [Archduke of Austria] :Königlicher Prinz von Ungarn [Prince Royal of Hungary]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oe24.at/oesterreich/chronik/habsburg/Letzter-Akt-fuer-Otto-Habsburg/34400069 |title=Letzter Akt für Otto Habsburg |publisher=Oe24.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-18}}</ref>

=== Vienna 16 July (requiem with subsequent procession and entombment in the Imperial Crypt)=== [[File:St. Stephen's Cathedral interior.JPG|thumb|The funeral ceremony took place in [[St. Stephen's Cathedral, Vienna]] on 16 July]] Many dignitaries attended the funeral in Vienna on 16 July. In total, around 1,000 invited guests were present, among them many royals, nobles, heads of state and government representatives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moz.de/nachrichten/vermischtes/artikel-ansicht/dg/0/1/337747/ |title=Requiem und Trauerzug für Otto von Habsburg-Lothringen |publisher=Moz.de |date= |accessdate=2011-07-08}}</ref>

{{flagicon|Montenegro}} [[House of Petrović-Njegoš]] – [[Crown Prince Nicholas II of Montenegro]]<ref name="Nikola Petrovic-Njegos first envoy of Prime Minister" >{{cite web |url= http://www.glas-javnosti.rs/aktuelne-vesti/2011-07-11/nikola-petrovic-njegos-prvi-put-izaslanik-premijera |title= Nikola Petrovic-Njegos first envoy of Prime Minister |work=glas-javnosti.rs |accessdate=18 July 2011 }}</ref>
;Representatives of state (in order of precedence) {{flag|VAT|name=Holy See}} – Pope Benedict XVI appointed Cardinal Christoph Schönborn as his personal representative to the funeral celebrations. Schönborn presided over the requiem in Vienna, as Archbishop of Vienna.<ref name="otsatschoenborn">{{cite web|url=http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung/OTS_20110706_OTS0259/kardinal-schoenborn-vertritt-papst-bei-habsburg-trauerfeiern |title=Kardinal Schönborn vertritt Papst bei Habsburg-Trauerfeiern |language=de |publisher=ots.at |date=2011-06-29 |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref>
[[File:Flag of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta.svg|22px|Order of Malta]] [[Order of Malta]] – Prince and Grand Master Fra' [[Matthew Festing]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kathweb.at/site/nachrichten/database/40510.html |title= Auch Malteser-Großmeister Festing kommt |publisher=Kathweb.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-14}}</ref>
{{flag|Austria}} – President [[Heinz Fischer]] and wife [[Margit Fischer]], Chancellor [[Werner Faymann]] and most of the Austrian cabinet and governors, and other representatives of state.<ref name="oe24-1">{{cite web|url=http://www.oe24.at/oesterreich/chronik/habsburg/Otto-Habsburg-So-wird-er-begraben/33289200 |title=Otto Habsburg: So wird er begraben |publisher=Oe24.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref>
{{flag|Hungary}} – President [[Pál Schmitt]]<ref name="oe24-at-guests"/>
{{flag|Georgia}} – President [[Mikheil Saakashvili]].<ref name="oe24-1" />
{{flag|Macedonia}} – Prime Minister [[Nikola Gruevski]]<ref name="diepresse-guests"/>
{{flag|Croatia}} – Prime Minister [[Jadranka Kosor]]<ref name="oe24-at-guests">{{cite web|url=http://www.oe24.at/oesterreich/chronik/habsburg/Schweden-Koenig-bei-Habsburg-Feier/33933105 |title=Schweden-König bei Habsburg-Feier |publisher=Oe24.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-12}}</ref>
{{flag|Czech Republic}} – Foreign Minister [[Karel Schwarzenberg]].<ref name="oe24-2" />
{{flag|Bavaria}} – Representatives of the government of [[Bavaria]] are expected.<ref name="kleinezeitung1" />
;Other {{flag|EU}} – [[Jerzy Buzek]],<ref name="kathweb1" /> [[Hans-Gert Pöttering]], [[Alejo Vidal-Quadras]].<ref name="oe24-2">{{cite web|url=http://www.oe24.at/oesterreich/chronik/habsburg/Habsburg-Die-Begraebnis-Gaesteliste/33385132 |title=Habsburg: Die Begräbnis-Gästeliste |publisher=Oe24.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-07}}</ref>
;Religious [[File:Insignia Germany Order Teutonic.svg|18px]] [[Teutonic Order]] - Hochmeister [[Bruno Platter]]
{{flag|Bosnia-Herzegovina}} – Grand Mufti [[Mustafa Cerić]] of Bosnia-Herzegovina<ref name="oe24-at-guests"/>
{{flag|Bavaria}} – Former Chief Rabbi Steven Langnas of Munich<ref name="oe24-at-guests"/>
===Budapest 17 July=== ;Royalty [[File:Flag of the Habsburg Monarchy.svg|22px|Habsburg flag]] [[House of Habsburg]] – [[Karl von Habsburg|Karl of Austria]], [[Georg von Habsburg|Georg of Austria]], [[Andrea von Habsburg|Andrea of Austria]], [[Monika von Habsburg|Monika of Austria]], [[Michaela von Habsburg|Michaela of Austria]], [[Gabriela von Habsburg|Gabriela of Austria]], [[Archduchess Walburga of Austria|Walburga of Austria]], and others
;Representatives of state {{flag|Hungary}} – President [[Pál Schmitt]], Prime Minister [[Viktor Orbán]], Deputy Prime Minister [[Zsolt Semjén]], and others<ref name="kathweb-hungary"/><ref name="kathweb-hungary17">{{cite web|url=http://www.kathweb.at/site/nachrichten/database/40560.html |title= Budapest: Staatspräsident und Vizepremier bei Habsburg-Requiem |publisher=Kathweb.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/otto-habsburg-the-last-surviving-heir-to-the-austro-hungarian-empire-has-been-buried/story-e6frg6so-1226096624821 |title=Otto Habsburg, the last surviving heir to the Austro-Hungarian empire, has been buried |publisher=The Australian |date= 18 July 2011|accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Lee Moran |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2015994/End-Royal-dynasty-Otto-von-Habsburg-laid-rest--heart-buried-crypt-85-miles-away-different-country.html |title=End of Royal dynasty as Otto von Habsburg is laid to rest... and his heart is buried in a crypt 85 miles away in different country |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date= 18 July 2011|accessdate=2011-07-19 |location=London}}</ref>
Members of the Diplomatic Corps and the [[Order of the Golden Fleece]]<ref name="kathweb-hungary17"/>
==Media coverage==
Around 300 journalists from Europe, America and Japan were accredited to cover the funeral in Vienna.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://diepresse.com/home/politik/innenpolitik/678579/Habsburg_Menschenschlangen-vor-der-Kapuzinerkirche |title=Habsburg: Menschenschlangen vor der Kapuzinerkirche |publisher=Diepresse.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref>
===Television broadcasts===
{{flagicon|Bavaria}} – The requiem in the Munich [[Theatine Church, Munich|Theatine Church]] on 11 July was broadcast live by [[Bayerischer Rundfunk]] (BR).
{{flagicon|Austria}} – [[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]] broadcast live for six hours from the Vienna funeral on 16 July. Before the live broadcast, ORF broadcast documentaries related to the Imperial-Royal Family.
On average, the 6-hour live broadcast was watched by 413,000 people in Austria, reaching 557,000 at the most.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://derstandard.at/1310511459243/Begraebnis-im-ORF-413000-nahmen-Abschied-von-Otto-Habsburg |title=413.000 nahmen 'Abschied von Otto Habsburg' |publisher=Derstandard.at |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref>
